componenttext: [Operator Instructions] We'll take our first question from Paul Coster with JPMorgan.

headline: First Solar, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 23, 2016
componenttextpreview: You're operating 100% utilization rate, you're intentionally pushing projects out into 2017. Can you sort of give us some sense as to whether you're leaving money on the table intentionally, turning down business? And what your visibility into 2017 is sta
componenttext: You're operating 100% utilization rate, you're intentionally pushing projects out into 2017. Can you sort of give us some sense as to whether you're leaving money on the table intentionally, turning down business? And what your visibility into 2017 is starting to look like?

headline: First Solar, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 23, 2016
componenttextpreview: We're not turning down very much business. The ability to push projects out has given us a little more flexibility in terms of available supply. And we continue to be very encouraged by the overall activity levels and the booking activity we're seeing or
componenttext: We're not turning down very much business. The ability to push projects out has given us a little more flexibility in terms of available supply. And we continue to be very encouraged by the overall activity levels and the booking activity we're seeing or the near-term possibility of bookings that we're seeing with respect to 2017.

headline: First Solar, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 23, 2016
componenttextpreview: We'll take our next question from Vishal Shah with Deutsche Bank.
componenttext: We'll take our next question from Vishal Shah with Deutsche Bank.

headline: First Solar, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 23, 2016
componenttextpreview: I wanted to just better understand your guidance in terms of what you're assuming for line upgrades and whether your previous guidance of 16.2% efficiency or for the full year still holds, and also what kind of expectations you have for bookings for the f
componenttext: I wanted to just better understand your guidance in terms of what you're assuming for line upgrades and whether your previous guidance of 16.2% efficiency or for the full year still holds, and also what kind of expectations you have for bookings for the full year 2016.

headline: First Solar, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 23, 2016
componenttextpreview: So, Vishal, on the efficiency. As we indicated, we're at, right now, 16.2%. We'll finish the quarter at 16.3%. We'll ramp that up as we progress through the year towards our lead line of 16.4%. So as we indicated in prior calls, we are intentionally looki
componenttext: So, Vishal, on the efficiency. As we indicated, we're at, right now, 16.2%. We'll finish the quarter at 16.3%. We'll ramp that up as we progress through the year towards our lead line of 16.4%. So as we indicated in prior calls, we are intentionally looking to optimize throughput, and as a result of that, we'll see less impact through our efficiency road map this year. So would we expect to see the 16.4% trend higher as we exit the year? Yes. But obviously, clearly not to the order of magnitude that we saw in 2015, which basically represented 160 basis points improvement year-on-year. But as we said before, we have a very competitive module right now. It's mid-16% efficiency. With the energy yield that we capture through temperature coefficient and spectral response, we're very happy with the competitiveness of our module. As it relates to bookings, bookings will continue to reflect ourself [ph]. And relative to our opportunity in our pipeline that we've identified, we're very happy with the growth that we've seen, now with over 20 gigawatts. We're happy with the 400-or-so megawatts that we booked since the last call, and a very good mix not only between systems and modules, but between U.S. and international. So again, as Jim indicated in his comments, the sales team is doing an outstanding job leveraging the core capabilities and the competitiveness of our technology.

headline: First Solar, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 23, 2016
componenttextpreview: And we'll take our next question from Brian Lee with Goldman Sachs.
componenttext: And we'll take our next question from Brian Lee with Goldman Sachs.

headline: First Solar, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 23, 2016
componenttextpreview: I just had 2 quick ones. On the 3 gigawatts that you added to the bookings opportunity since the last call, it's mostly from the U.S., as you acknowledged. Can you talk to what's really changed since the ITC was extended? Are these new projects coming int
componenttext: I just had 2 quick ones. On the 3 gigawatts that you added to the bookings opportunity since the last call, it's mostly from the U.S., as you acknowledged. Can you talk to what's really changed since the ITC was extended? Are these new projects coming into the mix? Or are these projects that were sort of on the fence already and you see more viability now with the ITC in place? And then related to that, what sort of visibility just on lead times would you say you have for turning these opportunities into bookings in '16 and '17?

headline: First Solar, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 23, 2016
componenttextpreview: So the -- it's a combination of a variety of those factors. The resolution of the ITC, I think, more than anything else, it's not any particular outcome with respect to the ITC, but it's removing the overhang of uncertainty and allows people to run their
componenttext: So the -- it's a combination of a variety of those factors. The resolution of the ITC, I think, more than anything else, it's not any particular outcome with respect to the ITC, but it's removing the overhang of uncertainty and allows people to run their models and be deterministic about what -- the financial conditions that they're going to be developing projects in. So it's allowed us to advance some of our own projects. It's allowed customers to advance their projects. It's firmed up what the financial environment looks like. The competitive environment has improved a little bit versus, let's say, 18 months ago. So it's a whole variety of factors. It's also a broadening of demand. We are seeing utilities express a desire to begin to participate in solar on a broader basis. We've had some very large customers that we've dealt with for quite a few years now, but we're adding to the customer sets. And we're getting inbound inquiries and seeing RFPs from other utilities. We're also seeing new developers come into the marketplace. They're in new service territories that we've not seen activity before. So it's the cumulative effect of a fairly broad set of circumstances. It's not one single thing that triggered it. It's very broad and across the board.

headline: First Solar, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 23, 2016
componenttextpreview: And we'll take our next question from Sven Eenmaa with Stifel.
componenttext: And we'll take our next question from Sven Eenmaa with Stifel.

headline: First Solar, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 23, 2016
componenttextpreview: I'd like to ask regarding mostly 2017. How do you think about the domestic versus international mix in that year? And how much of that will be kind of self-developed versus module and Module Plus sales?
componenttext: I'd like to ask regarding mostly 2017. How do you think about the domestic versus international mix in that year? And how much of that will be kind of self-developed versus module and Module Plus sales?

headline: First Solar, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 23, 2016
componenttextpreview: So I think it's a little early for us to have specific visibility. We have ample opportunity sets in both markets. I think that we will see a larger contribution from the U.S. versus what we would have thought, let's say, 9 to 12 months ago as a result of
componenttext: So I think it's a little early for us to have specific visibility. We have ample opportunity sets in both markets. I think that we will see a larger contribution from the U.S. versus what we would have thought, let's say, 9 to 12 months ago as a result of the ITC extension and the firming of demand. But it's a bit of a horse race. We've got lots of opportunities and lots of customers, and it's going to be a case of who gets their stuff over -- their opportunities over the finish line first with economics that look interesting. So it's a large opportunity set chasing a finite volume, so that's kind of the circumstance you want to find yourself in. So I don't -- I think there are some very big opportunities, both in the U.S. and internationally, that could dramatically impact what that mix looks like. And I think it's still a little early for us to have a precise visibility into how those big opportunities are going to play out, both in terms of do they get across the finish line, and then, two, some of them have uncertainty as to timing, whether they would be a '17 impact or potentially a later impact than that. So it's a little too early. All I can tell you is we have lots going on both internationally and in the U.S.

headline: First Solar, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 23, 2016
componenttextpreview: And we'll take our next question from Philip Shen with Roth Capital Partners.
componenttext: And we'll take our next question from Philip Shen with Roth Capital Partners.

headline: First Solar, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 23, 2016
componenttextpreview: With the OpEx guidance being maintained at $380 million to $400 million and with the ITC extension, can you speak to how much of your resources you're moving back to the U.S? And can you quantify the degree of international projects you may be leaving on
componenttext: With the OpEx guidance being maintained at $380 million to $400 million and with the ITC extension, can you speak to how much of your resources you're moving back to the U.S? And can you quantify the degree of international projects you may be leaving on the table or pushing out?

headline: First Solar, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 23, 2016
componenttextpreview: So we're not changing our resource allocation at all. We've built, over the last several years, with the focus on reining in OpEx and being a very lean, low-cost operation. We've also intentionally structured our operations so that we can leverage growth
componenttext: So we're not changing our resource allocation at all. We've built, over the last several years, with the focus on reining in OpEx and being a very lean, low-cost operation. We've also intentionally structured our operations so that we can leverage growth and future opportunities off of a given level of OpEx. We've spent a lot of time, debate, head-knocking internally over how do we build an organization and how do we structure our -- the business we're pursuing from a strategic standpoint so that we can leverage against that OpEx level. And the way the organization has been built, with the shared service centers we've built in some of our international locations, those resources and those centers can cost-effectively support our operations, whether they're in the U.S. or whether they're in almost any jurisdiction around the world. And so that gives us greater flexibility and relieves us of the need to redeploy resources. So we try to centralize certain resources in shared resource centers and centers of excellence that can be deployed anywhere, and then we have local resources that are focused, and we structure both of those activities so that they can be leveraged against greater opportunities without having to add to OpEx. So the proof that our efforts and concepts are working is the fact that we've been able to shift gears through the sort of changing market cycle without having to retool the organization. And it's given us -- it's demonstrated that we've built what we intended to build, which is a highly flexible, highly responsive organization that can adapt to changing market circumstances very quickly.

headline: First Solar, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 23, 2016
componenttextpreview: We'll take our next question from Patrick Jobin with Crédit Suisse.
componenttext: We'll take our next question from Patrick Jobin with Crédit Suisse.

headline: First Solar, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 23, 2016
componenttextpreview: Sorry to beat this to death here, just want to go back on '17, if I can. Jim, I think you mentioned previously the mix pressures moving away from systems in '17. But with these 2 projects pushing out and the late-stage opportunity set, mainly U.S. driven,
componenttext: Sorry to beat this to death here, just want to go back on '17, if I can. Jim, I think you mentioned previously the mix pressures moving away from systems in '17. But with these 2 projects pushing out and the late-stage opportunity set, mainly U.S. driven, potentially hitting '17, should we think about that as no longer being a pressure or a drag or could it be, I don't know, more of a positive element? And then just a follow-up item, you mentioned the competitive landscape has improved. So I guess some of the bids from a year ago or so that were pretty aggressive that perhaps might not get finished, are you sensing any opportunity to kind of be the rescue provider or potentially rebidding some of those contracts as near-term opportunities for you?

headline: First Solar, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 23, 2016
componenttextpreview: First, let's talk about the mix in '17. I would say, with the ITC extension, it does increase the sort of addressable opportunity set on the systems side within '17. In addition, I think in certain markets such as Japan, internationally, we have a pretty
componenttext: First, let's talk about the mix in '17. I would say, with the ITC extension, it does increase the sort of addressable opportunity set on the systems side within '17. In addition, I think in certain markets such as Japan, internationally, we have a pretty solid systems opportunity set that is addressable in '17 so it's not a dramatic shift. But there has been some increase in the relative weight of the 2, I would say. In terms of rebidding assets or capturing stress in the marketplace, we've looked at a lot of stuff. I think that the final stories are yet to be told in terms of the resolution of some of the assets in the marketplace. And I think we are also taking a very cautious approach to how much risk we're willing to take on board, particularly how much counterparty risk we're willing to take on board. We have a lot of high-quality opportunities, and I think we've, quite candidly, backed away a little bit from chasing stuff that's going to require us to take a bunch of risk. I think we're just continuing to execute down the path we were on and feel like that we can generate an outstanding shareholder result. That doesn't mean we won't be opportunistic, and that doesn't mean that we won't see things. We're just taking a cautious approach.

headline: First Solar, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 23, 2016

headline: First Solar, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 23, 2016
componenttextpreview: I wanted to just talk broadly about, as you compete day-to-day against other players, you're obviously making really strong improvements in your products' competitiveness, but of course, the competition is trying not to stand still as well. I'm wondering
componenttext: I wanted to just talk broadly about, as you compete day-to-day against other players, you're obviously making really strong improvements in your products' competitiveness, but of course, the competition is trying not to stand still as well. I'm wondering if you can speak to trends in terms of the competitiveness that you're seeing for your product versus others. Are you seeing the sort of, call it, the all-in economic value proposition for your product increasing in terms of its benefit relative to peers? Are you seeing that competition remains intense and other products are nipping at your heels? At a high level, can you speak to overall competitiveness?

headline: First Solar, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 23, 2016
componenttextpreview: Sure. So there's absolutely no doubt that the competition doesn't sit still, and they're endeavoring to improve their product at the same time as we are. However, if you go back to late 2012 through today, the rate of change of our efforts versus the comp
componenttext: Sure. So there's absolutely no doubt that the competition doesn't sit still, and they're endeavoring to improve their product at the same time as we are. However, if you go back to late 2012 through today, the rate of change of our efforts versus the competition is clearly significantly higher. And that's just something we'll spend some time on at the Analyst Day. But we have clearly been improving the relative value proposition, improving the margin entitlement, improving yield, energy density, across all markets, and we've been doing so at a higher rate of change than our competition. I can't speak to what they're going to do in the future, but we believe that we have a lot of opportunity in front of us in terms of continuing to drive our road map, and we'll talk a lot about that at our Analyst Day.

headline: First Solar, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 23, 2016
componenttextpreview: We'll take our next question from Krish Sankar with Bank of America Merrill Lynch.
componenttext: We'll take our next question from Krish Sankar with Bank of America Merrill Lynch.

headline: First Solar, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 23, 2016
componenttextpreview: Two quick ones. One is, Jim, if you look at the utilities scale market in the U.S., especially where you guys are targeting, the PPA prices have come down over the last several years. California and Nevada, we're hearing like $0.04 a kilowatt-hour PPA rat
componenttext: Two quick ones. One is, Jim, if you look at the utilities scale market in the U.S., especially where you guys are targeting, the PPA prices have come down over the last several years. California and Nevada, we're hearing like $0.04 a kilowatt-hour PPA rates. Do you think we're at a floor level for PPA? Or do you think there's more downside to this pricing? And the second follow-up is out of your 20.3 gigawatt pipeline, how much of that is modularly?

headline: First Solar, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 23, 2016
componenttextpreview: So on the PPA pricing, I don't think we're at "a floor level", but what you have to bear in mind, there's 2 primary components that drive that pricing, and one is the capital cost of the project itself, and that's both the module, the balance of system an
componenttext: So on the PPA pricing, I don't think we're at "a floor level", but what you have to bear in mind, there's 2 primary components that drive that pricing, and one is the capital cost of the project itself, and that's both the module, the balance of system and the development costs, which includes land, interconnect, permitting costs, et cetera. The other is the cost of capital. That's the return demanded by both debt and equity investors in the project. There's no reason to believe that cost road maps are not going to continue to decrease as we move forward in the future. Now I do think you will see some tendency to asymptote a little bit. I'm not sure the rate of change will be what it was several years ago, but there will continue to be a benefit moving forward. What is harder to predict is where are the capital markets going, what is the required rates of return on the part of investors and lenders going to be, and that's a little more of a crystal ball type of exercise. But if you assume constant capital cost, then there's no reason to believe that PPAs would be at a floor. And then on the mix of that, I don't believe we've ever shared the mix on that opportunity set, so I can't comment on that.

headline: First Solar, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 23, 2016

headline: First Solar, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 23, 2016
componenttextpreview: So can I just follow-up on that question, or your answer regarding the cost of capital? Obviously, we've seen light [ph] increase across the cost of capital in the energy space in general. How do you kind of think about that in terms of running your busin
componenttext: So can I just follow-up on that question, or your answer regarding the cost of capital? Obviously, we've seen light [ph] increase across the cost of capital in the energy space in general. How do you kind of think about that in terms of running your business and how is that impacted? And specifically, in certain part of solar, like residential, it seems like cost of capital has gone up pretty fast. Have you seen more competitors trying to go into utilities scale as a result of that? And then just quickly, any update on TetraSun?

headline: First Solar, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 23, 2016
componenttextpreview: So in terms of the way we think about it, we have always had a very deep pool of investors that we have tapped for -- to monetize the assets. Those investors' expectations in terms of return, we've seen variations over time, but the amplitude of those var
componenttext: So in terms of the way we think about it, we have always had a very deep pool of investors that we have tapped for -- to monetize the assets. Those investors' expectations in terms of return, we've seen variations over time, but the amplitude of those variations has been relatively mild. And we've also always been relatively conservative in terms of what we baked into our modeling in terms of what we could achieve in the marketplace. So the way we think about it is it's obviously a critical element to our development process. And so we spend a lot of time making sure we're in touch with the market, making sure we're in touch with our customers, making sure we have a sense of what's happening out there, and we certainly recognize it as an exposure if we didn't pay close attention to it. But we feel like, and we've demonstrated over the last several years, that we understand the market, and we know how to price our products so that we have the ability to monetize effectively. So it's sort of, yes, it's a big issue and it's a big risk, but that's core to succeeding in our business. And so managing that risk and understanding that risk is core to what we do. And what was the second question?

headline: First Solar, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 23, 2016

componenttext: So as it relates to pricing power, I mean, look, it all relates to energy density, and then what we've been trying to communicate over the last few calls, we've demonstrated the advantage that we have not only here in '15, but where we're going into '17 and beyond. And obviously, we're pricing forward with that type of advantage. So when you think about the spectral response advantage, the temperature coefficient advantage, which ultimately drives to an energy density advantage in the upwards of high single to low double-digit advantages, right? So we have quite a bit of pricing power relative to the technology. We have the advantage of the First Solar bankability and strength and the quality and reliability and willingness to stand behind our product over the long run. So I think that does translate into significant value in the marketplace. As it relates to the second -- the last question, Steve, I'm trying to remember what the last question...

componenttext: Cost of capital, yes. Cost of capital assumptions, we're not going to get into specifics around that. It varies by region. So as you think about what our cost of capital assumption is in Japan, it's dramatically different than what it is in the U.S., which is dramatically different than what it is in India. I wouldn't say that we're assuming any significant changes relative to current environment. We believe it will be relatively stable, maybe slightly higher in some regions, but we don't go into the specifics of what that assumption is by region.

headline: First Solar, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Good day, everyone, and welcome to the First Solar's First Quarter 2016 Earnings Call. This call is being webcast live on the Investors section of First Solar's website at firstsolar.com. [Operator Instructions]  As a reminder, today's call is being recor
componenttext: Good day, everyone, and welcome to the First Solar's First Quarter 2016 Earnings Call. This call is being webcast live on the Investors section of First Solar's website at firstsolar.com. [Operator Instructions]  As a reminder, today's call is being recorded. I would now like to turn the call over to Mr. Steve Haymore from First Solar Investor Relations. Mr. Haymore, you may begin.

headline: First Solar, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thank you. Good afternoon, everyone, and thank you for joining us. Today, the company issued a press release announcing its financial results for the first quarter of 2016. A copy of the press release and the presentation are available on the Investors se
componenttext:
Thank you. Good afternoon, everyone, and thank you for joining us. Today, the company issued a press release announcing its financial results for the first quarter of 2016. A copy of the press release and the presentation are available on the Investors section of First Solar's website at firstsolar.com. 
With me today are Jim Hughes, Chief Executive Officer; and Mark Widmar, Chief Financial Officer. Jim will provide a business and technology update, then Mark will discuss our first quarter financial results and provide updated guidance for 2016. We will then open up the call for questions.
Most of the financial numbers reported and discussed on today's call are based on U.S. Generally Accepted Accounting Principles. Please note this call will include forward-looking statements that involve risks and uncertainties that could cause actual results to differ materially from management's current expectations. We encourage you to review the safe harbor statements contained in today's press release and presentation for a more complete description.
It is now my pleasure to introduce Jim Hughes, Chief Executive Officer. Jim?

headline: First Solar, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Steve. Good afternoon and thank you for joining us today. Before we discuss our first quarter operational and financial results, I want to take a few minutes talk about the leadership transition we announced earlier today. As you may have seen i
componenttext:
Thanks, Steve. Good afternoon and thank you for joining us today. Before we discuss our first quarter operational and financial results, I want to take a few minutes talk about the leadership transition we announced earlier today. 
As you may have seen in our press release, after 4 years with First Solar as CEO, I have decided that I will step down on June 30 and hand the reigns over to our current Chief Financial Officer, Mark Widmar, who will assume the role of Chief Executive Officer at that time. As part of the transition, I will continue to support the company in an advisory role and as a member of the Board of Directors. 
The Board and I worked jointly on the company's leadership succession plan and Mark was our first and best choice as CEO as First Solar enters its next phase of growth. Mark is a strong, capable leader with an extensive knowledge of our business, having served as First Solar's Chief Financial Officer since 2011 and as First Solar's Chief Accounting Officer from February 2012 through June 2015. Mark and I have worked closely together over the past 4 years, and I expect a seamless transition. I have deep confidence that the company will be in good hands. 
It has been a privilege to lead First Solar, and I am proud of the significant milestones we accomplished as a team. When I joined First Solar in early 2012, the company faced significant challenges from both industry specific and macroeconomic factors. My intent from the start and my commitment to the Board of Directors was to work with First Solar leadership to establish a strategic plan that place the company on a trajectory of sustainable success. 
As our most recent Analyst Day demonstrated, we have accomplished what we set out to do 4 years ago. We not only achieved our goal, but we exceeded expectations. I remain excited about the opportunities ahead for First Solar. 
With that, let's turn to our results. I'll begin by briefly reviewing our first quarter operational and financial performance. First, our 30 manufacturing lines ran at 100% capacity utilization and produced over 770 megawatts of modules in the first quarter. Our Q1 fleet average efficiency continued to improve, climbing to 16.2%. Our lead line efficiency continues to hold steady at 16.4%, as new efficiency process improvements are not slated until later in the year. 
Coming off our recent Analyst Day, where we laid out a highly compelling technology roadmap and potential capacity expansions, this represents an impressive start to 2016 and to achieving the objectives outlined at that meeting. Turning to Slide 4, I'll review our latest comparison of bookings versus year-to-date shipments. 
We ended 2015 with 4.2 gigawatt DC of expected future module shipments. In the first quarter, we shipped over 800 megawatts of modules against this total and have booked approximately 600 megawatts of new volume. Of the 600 megawatts of new bookings, around 400 megawatts were booked since our last earnings call in late February. The largest single booking was the previously announced module supply agreement of over 200 megawatts DC with Silicon Ranch for deliveries to their projects scheduled for construction in 2017 and 2018. 
This agreement is another positive indication of the strength of solar demand in the Southeastern United States beyond 2016. International volume was an important component of our bookings since last earnings call with volume contracted in several different countries. 
In India, we signed module agreements for almost 100 megawatts DC of additional volume. As announced recently, we achieved a major milestone in this market with now over 1 gigawatt of volume sold into India. These new bookings at our strengthen in this lower growing solar market. 
In Honduras, we sent agreement with the Grupo Terra to provide modules and EPC services for a 25-megawatt AC solar projects. This is the second project in Honduras we would have constructed for Grupo Terra and further expands our presence in this region. 
For the balance of the year, we continue to see a number of domestic and international opportunity that would move us closer to a one-to-one book-to-bill ratio. In the U.S, the IPC extension has led to an increase in overall opportunities, but customers continue to work through revisions to project timing, which has led to some temporary delays in new contracted bookings. Potential international opportunities continue to be strong as well, with the decision timing on a number of projects occurring in the second half of the year. 
In addition, while the majority of bookings thus far in 2016 have been primarily module sales, this is timing related, as we are pursuing a number of systems booking opportunities during the balance of the year. 
For example, in our mid- to late-stage potential bookings, we have over 450 megawatts of opportunities with operating ranging from AC Power Block to a full powerplant. In our early stage opportunities, of we focus on the projects with the highest booking probability, there are over 500 megawatts of additional potential systems bookings. In each case, these are projects with 2017 COD and the majority of shipments occurring in that year. 
Note that in addition to the more than 950 megawatts of opportunities discussed, there are a large number of other early stage systems projects with lower probabilities that may materialize as well. 
Our bookings in terms of expected revenue announced at $6.4 billion, as shown on Slide 5. The decrease in expected revenue as a result of the timing of mid bookings thus far in 2016 and the higher mix of module only businesses compared to the revenue recognized in Q4. Now this includes revenue on any module sale or systems project that we have contracted. However, it does not include our contracted O&M revenue. 
Slide 6 provides the updated potential bookings opportunities, which is now over 23 gigawatts, an increase of approximately 3 gigawatts from the prior quarter. Our mid- to late-stage bookings opportunities are 3.1 gigawatt DC with international opportunities across 20 different countries comprising almost 90% of this number. Moving on to Slide 7. 
Our updated potential bookings opportunities by geography reflect the net increase in opportunities across all regions. The largest increase was in the United States, where new opportunities were identified across multiple regions. But especially in the South and Southeastern part of the country. 
We also had a significant increase in opportunities in the Middle East, India and Asia Pacific region. The growth and opportunities in these regions was the large number of mid-to late-stage international opportunities demonstrates the results of our multiyear effort we have made to diversify into new markets. 
I'll now turn it over to Mark, who will provide more detail on our first quarter financial results and discuss updated guidance for 2016.

headline: First Solar, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Jim, and good afternoon. Before I delve into that abyss, I would like to take this opportunity to express my heartfelt thanks to Jim for his leadership and friendship over the past 4 years. First Solar is a strong company it is today, thanks to hi
componenttext:
Thanks, Jim, and good afternoon. Before I delve into that abyss, I would like to take this opportunity to express my heartfelt thanks to Jim for his leadership and friendship over the past 4 years. First Solar is a strong company it is today, thanks to his guidance and dedication. I look forward to building success in the future. Come July, I will hit the ground running and work with our Board, management team and associates to drive First Solar's next phase of growth while continuing to deliver strong results to our shareholders. 
In addition, we announced today that Alex Bradley has been appointed Interim Chief Financial Officer. Alex has served as Vice President of Project Finance since 2012 with responsibility to the treasury group added last year. Alex has been with First Solar for 8 years and was instrumental in launching 8.3 energy partners last year. I have tremendous confidence in Alex's ability to step into the CFO role until a permanent successor has made. Now I'll begin by discussing our first quarter operational performance on Slide 9. 
In Q1, we produced 774-megawatt DC, an increase of 2% from the prior quarter due to higher module efficiency and increased throughput. Production was 43% higher compared to the first quarter of 2015, due to higher efficiencies, hip of throughput and the addition of new capacity. Our capacity utilization remained at 100% in Q1 and is 13 percentage points higher versus the same period in 2015. 
The higher year-over-year capacity utilization is due to fewer upgrade activities across the fleet. Our best line conversion efficiency remains unchanged at 16.4% as planned in our technology roadmap. Compared to the first quarter of 2015, our lead line efficiency improved by 80 basis points. 
Average module compares and efficiency in Q1 for our entire fleet was 16.2%, an increase of 10 basis points quarter-over-quarter. Year-over-year, our fleet average conversion efficiency increased by 150 basis points. As indicated at the recent Analyst Day, efficiency improvements are expected to pick up later in the year as we are targeting a full year average and lead line efficiency exit of 16.7% and 17%, respectively.
I'll next discuss the P&L results for the quarter on Slide 10. For Q1, net sales were $848 million in the quarter compared to $942 million in Q4. The decrease in the sale resulting primarily from the timing of revenue recognition across multiple projects and the completion during the quarter of our Penasco West and Seville projects. Module plus revenue declined from the prior quarter while third-party module sales increase slightly. Partially offsetting these decreases was the high revenue on our Stateline project with resulted from an amendment to the regional sales agreement with Southern to include an additional 15% interest in the project. This leaves First Solar with the remaining 34% interest, which is expected to be dropped down to 8.3% in the second half of the year. 
As highlighted at the Analyst Day, the sale of the mental interest in Stateline does not impact our full year guidance, but does have the effect of shifting earns out from the second half of the year into the first half. As a percent of total quarterly net sales, or solar power systems revenue, which includes both our EPC revenue and solar modules used in systems projects, decreased to 93% from 95% in the prior quarter. 
Gross margin for the quarter was 31% compared to 24.6% in the fourth quarter. The improved margin percentage resulting from the higher mix of Stateline revenue and significant system cost improvements. Our component segment gross margin improved to over 28% in the quarter and benefited from a lower module cost per watt. 
Operating expenses decreased by almost $2 million from Q4 to $98 million. R&D expenses were lower versus the prior quarter, partially offset by higher development staff. First quarter operating profit was $165 million compared to an operating profit of $130 million in the prior quarter. 
Other income and expense was $36 million for the quarter, primarily due to a $38 million gain from the sale and rebalancing of certain restricted investments associated with our module end-of-life program. The transaction was completed in order to better align the currencies of the investments with those of the corresponding collection and recycling obligations. The gain was approximately $20 million net of tax. 
Tax expense for Q1 was $34 million, including the tax on the gains from the sale of our restricted investments. Q1 earnings were $1.66 per fully diluted share on net income of $171 million. This compares to earnings of $1.60 in the prior quarter. 
Overall, it was a strong quarter for earnings in a positive start for 2016. We were able to settle incremental Stateline, which not only strengthens our ongoing relationship with Southern, but also provides greater flexibility for 8.3. Our manufacturing systems operations performing well in the quarter and contributed significantly into Q1 results. 
Turning to Slide 11. I'll now discuss the selected budget items to cash flow summary. Cash and remarkable securities increased by approximately $50 million to $1.9 billion. Our net cash position also increased to $1.6 billion. The improvement was achieved while our project related our asset balance grew to $1.5 billion from $1.3 billion in the prior quarter. 
For the quarter, net working capital, including the change in noncurrent project assets and excluding cash and marketable securities, increased slightly as compared to Q4. The increase in project-related assets was partially offset by a reduction in accounts receivable. 
Total debt increased by $10 million from the prior quarter to $299 million, as payments on our tail and debt facility were more than offset by additional financings for international projects. Cash flow from operation was $50 million, slightly lower as compared to Q4. Free cash flow was $30 million compared to $20 million in Q4. 
Capital expenditures were $52 million as compared to $27 million in the prior quarter. Depreciation for the quarter was $55 million or approximately $5 million lower than the prior quarter. Continuing to Slide 12, I will now discuss our updated full year 2016 guidance. 
First, note that while the strong Q1 results could be perceived as the catalyst for a more substantial increase in our earnings guidance, it is important to keep in mind the factors that contribute to the revised guidance. 
First, the amendment to the original Stateline sales agreement did not impact full year earnings, rather it affected the timing of the earnings and the income statement presentation. In addition, we feel it's too early in the year to make more substantial updates to the guidance. While we have visibility opportunities during the balance of the year that could result in making an upward provision, we believe a more measured approach at this time is prudent. 
Turning to our guidance on net sales. We're keeping the range of $3.8 billion to $4 billion. We are making -- maintaining the range primarily based on expected accounting for the sale of timber project, which we will reflect in our Q2 results. The tax equity structuring for this project sale will result in a partial deferral of revenue. We will provide more information related to this transaction on the Q2 call. But for now, we are highlighting that it's a factor in holding the net sales guidance and change. 
Next, we're increasing our gross margin guidance range by 100 basis points to a revised range of 18% to 19%. The gross margin improvement is a result of the amendment to the regional Stateline project sale was result in movement of profit from equity earnings to gross margin. In addition, the cost improvements in the first quarter have benefited gross margin and are reflected in the updated range. 
It's important to keep in mind that the expected profit on the sale of our remaining 34% interest in Stateline is still reflected in equity and earnings in our guidance. Operating expenses is unchanged and operating income guidance has increased by $40 million, reflecting the improved gross margin. 
The effective tax rate is unchanged at 16% to 18%. We have increased the low end of our guidance per share -- earnings per share guidance to $4.10 and left the high end unchanged at $4.50. As noted on Slide 12, our EPS guidance includes approximately $145 million net of tax from the exec of sale of our remaining interest in Stateline and First Solar share of 8.3's earnings. 
In addition, approximately $0.20 of other income net of tax is included in the earnings guidance range from the Q1 sale of the restricted investments, \ mentioned. Distribution of earnings for the year is expected to be slightly less than 50% in the first half of there, although it is a subject that's timing certain project sales close. 
Our expected ending net cash balance is unchanged and operating cash flow range have increased by $100 million compared to our prior guidance. The increase in operating cash flow had the net 0 impact to the overall cash balance as it is a movement from investing to operating cash flow. 
With the sale of an incremental 15% interest in Stateline to Southern, the cash associated with this transaction will be treated as operating cash flow rather than the prior expectations of an investing cash flow from the sale of the residual interest in the project to 8.3. Keep in mind that our operating cash flow guidance does not include approximately $320 million from the expected sale of the remaining interest in Stateline to 8.3, which we expect to be treated as investing cash flows. 
Our capital expenditure to shipment guidance remains unchanged. CapEx guidance in the year, it should be noted that included in this number is approximately $130 million related to the launch of our series 5 project, which we introduced recently at our Analyst Day. Our drop-down plans for Kimber, Stateline and more to 8.3 are unchanged however, the actual execution are subject to market conditions. 
Finally, in our recent Analyst Day, some has expressed concerns that we did not provide more specifics around 2017. I wish to reiterate that there are still a number of moving pieces and uncertainties related to 2017, which do not make it meaningful to provide an outlook at this time. They'll reality should not overshadow the significant opportunities and technology advances we have laid out in detail at the event. We feel the company is better position than in any time during the past 5 years from a technology, operational and balance sheet strength standpoint, and we look forward to the many opportunities to come. 
Turning to the next like, I'll summarize our progress during the past quarter. First, we delivered solid financial results for the first quarter with gross margins of 31% and earnings per share of $1.66. We updated our 2016 earnings guidance range from $4.10 to $4.50, which represents a $0.05 increase of our guidance mid-point. 
Our technology performance continues at a strong place with a fleet average efficiency of 16.2% and a best line of 16.4%. We have booked 600-megawatt so far this year, and we continue to see the number of opportunities increase and our potential bookings now stand at over 23 gigawatts. 
With a number of opportunities in the second half of the year, we see anticipated the booking momentum to continue. With this, we'll conclude our prepared remarks and open the call for questions. Operator?

headline: First Solar, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: [Operator Instructions] And we'll now take our first question from Vishal Shah with Deutsche Bank.
componenttext: [Operator Instructions] And we'll now take our first question from Vishal Shah with Deutsche Bank.

headline: First Solar, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Jim, congratulations. And Mark, I wanted to just follow up on your comments for 2017. I think you guys mentioned in the prepared remarks that there was 450-megawatt of systems bookings opportunities that you expect to be included in the second half. So ba
componenttext: Jim, congratulations. And Mark, I wanted to just follow up on your comments for 2017. I think you guys mentioned in the prepared remarks that there was 450-megawatt of systems bookings opportunities that you expect to be included in the second half. So based on some of the backlog that you announced, should we think about systems business in the 800 to 900-megawatt range for next year? Is that the starting point? And then, as you think about CapEx for next year, can you just maybe provide what how should we think about either CapEx and capacity then for the remainder of this year and next year?

headline: First Solar, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. So I think what we said is just comments in our late stages, I think it was maybe about 450. But we also indicated that if you look at the earlier stage products , these are the ones that with return higher level probability this another 500 megawatt
componenttext:
Yes. So I think what we said is just comments in our late stages, I think it was maybe about 450. But we also indicated that if you look at the earlier stage products , these are the ones that with return higher level probability this another 500 megawatts or so in there. 
So there's a potential about a gigawatt of bookings of that can happen between now and the end of the year that will be systems related. That's also one reason why, as we think about providing guidance for 2017, until we crystallize of those opportunities, it is not meaningful at this point in time to provide guidance for '17. Just want to make sure you kind of [indiscernible]. 
But as it relates to next year's summer in that gigawatt range, the systems level, that's probably about right. We've kind of indicated that we would expect it to be maintained at around that range, at least in the foreseeable future, trending upwards obviously as we start to ramp capacity. So I think that's the right way to look at it. 
CapEx, just really point you back to what we said in the Analyst Day at this point in time. We gave the view of what we see capacity expansion. We gave the view of what the associated CapEx would be for that capacity expansion. We haven't given the street impact to '17, '18 versus '19. But I think the best thing to do is just go back and review the slide that we presented at the Analyst Day. I think that will give you the color that we're looking for.

componenttextpreview: Yes. So when you think about fin the guidance, we brought about 50% in the first half, 50% in the second half. So really where we are right now it's kind of transition every period for our systems business. So we are starting to see project such as Silver
componenttext: Yes. So when you think about fin the guidance, we brought about 50% in the first half, 50% in the second half. So really where we are right now it's kind of transition every period for our systems business. So we are starting to see project such as Silver State South and Macquarie and even Stateline start to ramp down. At the same time, we're starting to see other projects like seeing flags we haven't sold were expecting mop by the second half, and then we're seeing our 6 station projects started to ramp-up in the second half of the year as well. So it's really -- it's a rum down of some of our systems Project of been in construction over the last year, and then we don't start to see a ramp-up with the new assets until we start to enter into the July timeframe. So it's just a transitionary period. So we'll see more module only type of and Module Plus type revenue in the second quarter. So you see us like properties associated with that. In terms of capacity, visibility. It's -- as we always said, it's going to be driven by highly reliable predictable demand. And so it's a demand driven poll versus a capacity push. And we're starting to see, obviously, not only here in the U.S. but internationally, a significant increase in demand in our pipe and what's reflected in our pipeline. When you can see there's a lot more international. So it's not necessarily discrete to one, but you do region it's not discrete to module versus systems. And so it's a holistic comprehensive analysis of the global demand expectations across all 4 product offering talk ultimate kind of perform our view of around capacity ad the right time to add it.

headline: First Solar, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Just a couple of follow-up. One thing to understand about the systems business is even though the ITC got extended, we had a large number of system projects that were slated for delivery in 2016. And some of those had PPA requirements such that even thoug
componenttext: Just a couple of follow-up. One thing to understand about the systems business is even though the ITC got extended, we had a large number of system projects that were slated for delivery in 2016. And some of those had PPA requirements such that even though the ITC was extended, they still have to the delivered. So we had a, what I call, an unusual alignment of deliveries at the end of 2016. And that leaves a bit of a gap until you can redeploy the workforce, start new projects and get those projects to the finish line. And that's a little bit of what we're seeing.  We're seeing plenty of demand. But normally, our systems business, the project sort of roll off at a steady rate as opposed to all being aligned to a single point in time. So it's a little bit of a historical function of the ITC -- of the ITC follow that never happened because it got extended. So I think that's just an important thing to keep in mind. The other is, one of the things we tried to highlight at the Analyst Day, and I think people need to try to get a greater understanding of this. We've got a number of factors coming together in terms of our production platform. We've got a new product we're rolling out in the form of the series 5. We have a new product under development in the form of the series 6. There's a lot of complicated decisions that we need to make about the production platform related to those. And we are trying to make sure that is we're thoughtful, careful and detailed in our analysis. So it's not as simple as, what's the demand and when do we build the plant to supply it? It's a more complicated equation because we've got new products in the equation. So it's -- we will respond to demand when and where we see it, and we will also communicate to investors when we have a clear view of what our plans going to be. But as we always have been, you're always going to be a little bit conservative and a lipid thoughtful about putting those plans together.

headline: First Solar, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: So the last 4 years, we had a couple of overriding factors that drove a lot of what we were trying to accomplish as a company. One was we wanted to restore cost leadership and substantially improve our technology. And that was an overwhelming sort of focu
componenttext:
So the last 4 years, we had a couple of overriding factors that drove a lot of what we were trying to accomplish as a company. One was we wanted to restore cost leadership and substantially improve our technology. And that was an overwhelming sort of focus of what we wanted to do. 
In addition, you had -- the potential ICC fall away, which created a very significant distortion in the marketplace. And you were trying to plan around that distortion. And it's not an easy business task to sort of flow those 2 together and figure it out. As I look at the tests in that market and the team are going to take on over the next 4 years, we have a much clearer view demand with no big distorting events within the next sort of 4 to 5 year time horizon at least that we know about today. And we have a position of technology leadership that we're going to increase upon as opposed to try to get back to and achieve. So I think it will be a little less lumpy and feel a little more robust than perhaps the last 4 years, where we have a lot of challenges to overcome, which we successfully overcame. I think this is less of our overcoming challenges and more about capital by the strong the incredible opportunities of that are out there for the company.

So you've got a little over 3 gigawatts and 90% of that is actually international. It is relatively diverse. It's in a number of markets. I mean, we're seeing a lot of activity clearly in India, but we're starting to see more activity across Asia Pacific, seeing activity through the Mideast. We're starting to see -- gradually just closed to signing an agreement in South America for about 40 megawatts. So there's a lot of opportunities even in South Africa. So it's a very diverse, and that's what we wanted to see. I mean, over the years, we made a decision to invest in our demand generation in our sales team. And we felt that over time, we will great diversity of the demand profile. And then that starting to show off and it's reflected in our pipeline. So it's not anyone discrete market. It's pretty robust. That's what we want to see and that type of diversification.

headline: First Solar, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: So the, I think everybody is going to get a bit of an education on the bankruptcy process over the next 6 to 9 months. The Bankruptcy Court has very broad powers to deal with contracts that Sun Edison has entered into. Utilities will not be able to termin
componenttext: So the, I think everybody is going to get a bit of an education on the bankruptcy process over the next 6 to 9 months. The Bankruptcy Court has very broad powers to deal with contracts that Sun Edison has entered into. Utilities will not be able to terminate in those contracts even if they have the right to do so without the approval of the Bankruptcy Court. So I think what you will see happen is they'll be a long period of uncertainty. I personally don't think we're going to see a lot of progress are lot of definition around their projects. We're certainly the next 3 to 4 months and probably closer to 6 months. And then as the creditors committee and the bankruptcy state works through all of the mechanics of bankruptcy that have to figure out everything and that's going to be challenged as a preference. Everything that's going to be  challenge's as a fraudulent conveyance and bear in mind, the very large transactions that were done in the year prior to the bankruptcy signing, there will have to work through the big pieces of litigation with the yield close and the failed deals and try to solve all of that. So if bankruptcies go, there's a lot of big issues that are going to be help dealt with before I think they can get to some of them are mundane sort of ordinary source of business types of issues. And So the impact of the market whether the violence are going to get built and whether utilities are going to re. Europe, that's simply think that, that will play out very slowly over the remainder of 2016.

What kind of risks is therefore -- pushback from your customers? And they have any contingency plans in place in case you get too much pushback, especially when one factor?

headline: First Solar, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: So there's not been a lot of pushback from customers. There's generally been an enthusiastic response from customers, especially in the North American circumstance, which is where the economics work the best. There are projects or bidding opportunities ou
componenttext: So there's not been a lot of pushback from customers. There's generally been an enthusiastic response from customers, especially in the North American circumstance, which is where the economics work the best. There are projects or bidding opportunities out there where we have qualification issues for Series 5. It's not been in existence long enough to qualify. That's not really a challenge for us because we're going to continue to manufacture Series 4 as far as into the future vacancy. And we can also adjust the ratio of Series 4 to series 5 production relatively easily. It's the same basic pressure platform with a different back and added. So there's a great deal with flexibility and shifting production between the Series 4 and series 5. And as we begin to see where the demand is going to be over '17, '18 and '19 and begin to see where the adoption of Series 5 is going to be, we'll be able to tailor sort of the rollout of that and adjust the production of 4 versus 5 fairly easily. So I don't think we feel like there's a lot of challenge in that -- in those issues.

componenttext: Just 2 quick follow-up items here or housekeeping items rather. I think in your remarks, you said in the asset sale, research and asset was included in guidance. And then the second question is backing into about $0.50 ASP figure here, I guess, that was all modules for bookings in the quarter. I'm just rang to get a sense relative to that $0.50 ASP.

headline: First Solar, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. So on the asset sales, I mean, we included the investment, the gain on the sale of the restricted investments as we rebalance the portfolio to again better match of the currency of those investments with the currency of the obligations. So that happe
componenttext: Yes. So on the asset sales, I mean, we included the investment, the gain on the sale of the restricted investments as we rebalance the portfolio to again better match of the currency of those investments with the currency of the obligations. So that happened during the quarter. And as I indicated, it's about $0.20 [indiscernible] that is our guidance for the full year. As it relates to other asset sales, there are not any other items in our guidance at this point in time. Are there any other potential asset sales that could happen during the balance of the year? There's a couple -- we still have facilities in Europe and Asia Pacific that we are marketing. There's always potential opportunity. That something like that could happen but is now assume benefit of that included our guidance at this point in time. Look, we're very confident in our ability to extract value from the module and the energy density advantages that we have. And we showed that in the Analyst Day there that advantage will improve over time. And then, with series 5 in particular, when you normalize for subsequently the same form factor as Crystalline silicon. There's advantages, we talked about that in terms of labor costs, the fewer connectors and those types of things that will help drive down the cost of that product as it relates to the overall cost to install. So we're very comfortable in terms of translating our Technology Advantage and ultimately normalizing the 4 factor that, that will translate into Valley. The bookings, yes. The bookings that were reflected in the quarter were primarily modules. And there was -- I'll refer to it as low bin inventory that we sold during the quarter that would be below market expectations around value for the module. So there were some of that. We ended up some. It was around 40 megawatts or so. So that did bring down the average ASP that supplied by the booking. I also will tell you is that there is running at those numbers. So I understand the simple [indiscernible] math is going to tell you that there is around it both ways that will get you to that exact same answer.

componenttext: I have 3 quick ones. First one is the rest of the business Stateline about 35% or so the dividend dropped into 8.3. Is it all really happened in calendar '16 or do you think it could spill over into early '17? The second one is in terms of the module supply added by you guys, but given by some of the Asian makers, do you worry about any kind of oversupply in the second half of this year for modules? And the final question is Jim congratulations. And curious on the timing of the transition. If you can give us any color or any talk process behind it, why now? And it will be very helpful.

headline: First Solar, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Sure. First on the timing of the transition. Succession is something we have now been discussing for quite a while. And this -- I would describe this as perhaps slightly accelerated from anywhere we would have thought it was going to be 1 year ago, but it
componenttext: Sure. First on the timing of the transition. Succession is something we have now been discussing for quite a while. And this -- I would describe this as perhaps slightly accelerated from anywhere we would have thought it was going to be 1 year ago, but it was clearly a plan of that we had in place. We've taken some more organizational steps to prepare for us, some of which the market was aware of. It -- we're transitioning from one strategic plan that we satisfied and we're embarking upon a second division 2020 plan. We have a lot of big fundamental decisions. They're good decisions. They're, how are we going to best capitalize on opportunities? And I think the Board and I felt like that this was the right time to let a new manage -- the new management team coalesce around those decisions. So that they don't have my heavy hand hanging over them and they reflect the views, the thoughts and the beliefs of that team because obviously, both I and the Board want that team to be accountable for meeting the results that are promised. So just for a variety of reasons it felt like the right time. It felt that way to the Board. Felt that way to be. Mark was comfortable that it was the right time to transition in terms of available to fill his role at least on an interim basis. So it's a variety. It's a whole variety reasons, and everybody's very, very comfortable with it.

headline: First Solar, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: The other one I think you had was a Stateline. We still have a 34% interest in Stateline. The guidance assumes that we drop in that down into 8point3 this year. We always said that there is optionality around that. And as you know, this is in our comments
componenttext: The other one I think you had was a Stateline. We still have a 34% interest in Stateline. The guidance assumes that we drop in that down into 8point3 this year. We always said that there is optionality around that. And as you know, this is in our comments, our prepared comments, we said in our current plan is to drop down Kingbird, Moapa and Stateline to 8point3, but we also highlight is subject to market execution, then conditions. So there could be some issue timing wise as it relates to that and we have flexibility if we wanted to take Stateline into next year or portion of Stateline if we chose to do that. So that optionality will play itself out subject to many different variables as we progress through the second half of the year. As it relates to oversupply concerns, we always have kind of a healthy dense and concern of what's going on in the market. And we said before the ITC extension that there was a concern around oversupply as we went into '17. Clearly, I think the ITC extension provides a different view of the horizon beyond '16. We may not have as much resiliency or robustness of the men in '17, but clearly drives more demand into '18, '19 and '20. In particular, we are very -- a very encouraged by where the international markets are trending. A lot of new opportunities happening internationally. But we are obviously, aware of what's going on. In terms of what the additional plans are and the education is relative to demand. What I will say though as well, as we increase the overall competitiveness of our products, especially as new Series 4 to 5 and then eventually get into Series 6. We believe we have a very strong differentiated technology and cost advantage technology that will weather those types of potential disruptions around supply and demand.

componenttext: Can you talk a little bit about the pricing dynamics as you move throughout the year and into back half of the year? Relative to the kind of clarity that works like going to get out of China in terms of the policy and talk a little bit about ability to have pricing power in the market as you move into the higher efficiency range with your products and back half of this year and into next year?

headline: First Solar, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: So I'll comment a little and then I'll let Mark add to it. The dynamics in pricing vary from market to market. And there are some markets where we feel like we have leverage. Often time, that's tied to specific competitive factors related to technology or
componenttext: So I'll comment a little and then I'll let Mark add to it. The dynamics in pricing vary from market to market. And there are some markets where we feel like we have leverage. Often time, that's tied to specific competitive factors related to technology or customer relationships. Other markets, less so. I'd say, at this stage, with respect to the back half of the year and certainly, for next year, we're still in a mode where we are optimizing sales against margin. In other words, we're not chasing every opportunity that presents itself. We have the ability to pick and choose the opportunities that we're chasing in order to maximize the margin on every incremental sales that we achieved. So that is generally indicative of an environmental where I wouldn't say we have pricing power, but we have that ability to optimize. So that's a sign of at least -- while it's a reasonable size helps with respect to the market, I guess, is how I would describe it..

headline: First Solar, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: The only thing, I guess, I would add to that is just it does vary by region. It varies by customer and ultimately what is our overall customer relationship with that particular customer and their understanding of kind of the First Solar value proposition
componenttext: The only thing, I guess, I would add to that is just it does vary by region. It varies by customer and ultimately what is our overall customer relationship with that particular customer and their understanding of kind of the First Solar value proposition and bankability. So it all does somewhat vary. And so you can see different behaviors across region based on the customers and what they value and ultimately, if they look upon to long-term owner of the asset or they looked by just be the developer that cell down of the asset plus all that comes into play as we think about how to engage the customer and then ultimately how do we capture the best value for our product. Now, as a Jim indicated because we have optionality that placed our strength, right so we will target of those types of opportunities and we can capture the highest margin entitlement relative to the product and solutions that we provided to the customer.

componenttextpreview: So we're continuing to assess and evaluate -- work very closely with SunPower as well as the independent directors of the Board of 8point3 Energy. Understanding kind of curve market dynamics, the ability to drop down projects that are accretive for it 8po
componenttext: So we're continuing to assess and evaluate -- work very closely with SunPower as well as the independent directors of the Board of 8point3 Energy. Understanding kind of curve market dynamics, the ability to drop down projects that are accretive for it 8point3, as well as provide drive returns for shareholders. We still believe that there's a tremendous value and our investment, I guess, the best way to see it a shareholder of 8point3. Clearly there are some market dislocations right now that are impacting that. We believe over time the investor will better understand quality of these assets, the investor grade off takers, the relatively low variability around the solar assets. The equity will perform over time. Now whether that completely happens in time for us to drop-down walk and Stateline, yet to be sure. We'll evaluate that and we have other options if we choose to pursue them. Similar to what we did with the Stateline when we sold a portion of Stateline to Southern we -- and then, inclusive the ROFO by identifying switch, which is a large project that will take the COD at 2017 as a potential drop down to 8point3. So if you make a decision around one of the other assets, it was Stateline, we have more than enough contracted assets that if we chose to, we could replace them in ROFO and put them into the cadence with some more natural drop down to 8point3. As we said in the 8point3 earnings call, we already have with the current assets that have been drop-down with Oprah Henrietta be completed here recently, Hooper and work being completed here recently, we have the ability to grow our dividend through the end of '17. So we have a luxury of optionality and patience, and we'll evaluate that and see what makes the most sense over time.
