componenttext: Good afternoon, everyone, and welcome to First Solar's Second Quarter 2016 Earnings Call. This call is being webcast live on the Investors section of First Solar's website at firstsolar.com. [Operator Instructions] As a reminder, today's call is being recorded. I would now like to turn the call over to Steve Haymore from First Solar Investor Relations. Mr. Haymore, you may begin.

headline: First Solar, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thank you. Good afternoon, everyone, and thank you for joining us. Today, the company issued a press release announcing its financial results for the second quarter of 2016. A copy of the press release and the presentation are available on the Investors s
componenttext:
Thank you. Good afternoon, everyone, and thank you for joining us. Today, the company issued a press release announcing its financial results for the second quarter of 2016. A copy of the press release and the presentation are available on the Investors section of First Solar's website at firstsolar.com. With me today are Martin Widmark, Chief Executive Officer; and Alex Bradley, Interim Chief Financial Officer. Mark will provide a business and technology update and then, Alex will discuss our second quarter financial results and provide updated guidance for 2016. We will then open up the call for questions. 
Most of the financial numbers reported and discussed on today's call are based on U.S. generally accepted accounting principles. In the few cases where we report by GAAP measures, such as free cash flow or non-GAAP earnings per share, we had reconciled the non-GAAP measures to GAAP measures at the back of our presentation. Please note this call will include forward-looking statements that involve risks and uncertainties that could cause actual results to differ materially from management's current expectations. We encourage you to review the safe harbor statements contained in today's press release and presentations for a more complete description. 
It is now my pleasure to introduce Mark Widmar, Chief Executive Officer. Mark?

headline: First Solar, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Steve. Good afternoon, and thank you for joining us today. Before reviewing the results for the quarter, I want to provide a brief update on some key strategic priorities, and how I intend to lead the organization in my new role as CEO. In our dec
componenttext:
Thanks, Steve. Good afternoon, and thank you for joining us today. Before reviewing the results for the quarter, I want to provide a brief update on some key strategic priorities, and how I intend to lead the organization in my new role as CEO. In our decision-making, we will continue to apply the same disciplined approach to long-term strategy that has served us extremely well today. At various signs over the last several years, some have questioned our measured approach, the key strategic positions including capacity expansion, asset ownership and balance sheet utilization. However, we continue to see the benefits of our discipline strategy and are confident this approach will optimize shareholder value over the long term. This approach also allows us to be nimble and navigate an industry that is cyclical, high growth and dynamic. The updates I will provide today do not constitute any major strategic changes from what we discussed earlier this year at our Analyst Day in April but are for the refinements aimed at simplifying and focusing our business. 
The core of our overall strategy continues to be our differentiated cash cell technology and its tremendous potential for further conversion efficiency improvements. Closely aligned, to our module efficiency road map is the evolution of our module form factor, which as we indicated in April, will begin next year with the introduction of our Series 5 module. Our Series 4 technology is an outstanding product with a superior temperature coefficient, gain and shading response. Series 4 holds an energy density advantage over multi-crystalline silicon products. Series 5 retains the energy density of that cash held technology, further boosts efficiency and is optimized for cost-effective installations. To put into perspective, in a typical market, the reduction in Series 5 OS costs relative Series 4 will be equivalent to boosting module efficiency by approximately 100 basis points. The combination of these factors make this a powerful new product, which is supported by positive initial feedback from our customers and partners. 
Given the exciting potential of this product, we are now planning to invest in additional efficiency improvements over the next couple of years that will take the Series 5 road map to a 391 module versus the 365-watt module were introduced at the Analyst Day. A competitive position of the Series 5 390 watt module with a similar form factor to crystalline silicon but with the inherent energy advantage is very exciting. Moreover, the substantial increase to the Series 5 road map has an extremely comparing them a compelling return on investment. The estimated $60 million of capital expenditures that we will require to enable this efficiency gain across our current 3 gigawatts of production will result in an anticipated payback time of less than a year. 
The focusing on increasing Series 5 efficiency does not change the priority we are placing on Series 6. We continue to push pace Series 6 development as fast as possible with power plant production beginning in 2018. It should be noted that we intend to prioritize long-term investment in the production and development of Series 5 and Series 6 technologies over adding new manufacturing capacity in the short term. In light of the current supply demand dynamics in the global market, we will continue to evaluate the point in time in which adding additional capacity makes sense. 
As we eagerly look forward to the exciting technologies, some strategic realignments are necessary to ensure focus and seamless execution. Firstly, as we recently announced, we have decided to discontinue TetraSun production in order to maximize our Series 5 assembly capabilities at our facility in Malaysia. This not only enables a more rapid roll-out of Series 5 product next year but also allows us to focus more resources and capital on our cad tel road map. Secondly, the new Series 5 form factor would significantly spectrum of third-party structures and tracker technologies available for use with our modules without requiring First Solar specific components. Previously, the different form factor of our Series 4 technology led us to develop optimized in-house solutions. The new interoperability of Series 5 with a broad ecosystem of existing third-party structure products is expected to facilitate increase adoption of our module by new customers and increased market opportunities. 
The evolution of our module form factor allows us to tap into a broader and deeper supply chain for structures and trackers and we have therefore decided to discontinue substantial internal development of flexibility and tracker structures. This position allows us to refocus resources towards developing closer relationships with industry-leading structure and tracker technology providers and, at the same time, eliminate some of the channel conflicts that existed in certain situations today. 
Thirdly, the progression of interoperability of our modules also impacts our strategy as it relates to EPC capabilities. Historically, we have so performed EPC on the majority of our system projects as well as provide EPC services to third-party developers using first solar module technology. The evolution of our module form factor, combined with the lower volume of system projects in 2017, implies a reduced need for internal EPC services and requires a reduction in our EPC work force. While these decisions are difficult and will impact a number of dedicated associates, this is a necessary step. We will continue to maintain sufficient internal EPC resources to support the construction of our self develop projects. This allows us continue to provide comprehensive solutions to our customers and also enables continued development of next-generation BLS technologies, such as NBCC which we introduced at our Analyst Day. 
It should be clear that this position around EPC can no way impacts our product development business and in fact allows us to allocate more capital and focus more resources on this critical aspect of our business model. 
Lastly, as part of our refocusing efforts, we have also decided to explore options for the disposition of sky tron in energy. Our original intent in acquiring sky tron was to expand our global O&M footprint into Europe and supplement our existing capabilities. Over the past 2 years, competition for winning contracts in Europe, combined with progression of First Solar's internal O&M capability, particularly as it relates to smaller-scale solar plants, has changed how [indiscernible] fits into our strategy going forward. 
Altogether, we expect charges of $105 million to $120 million related to TetraSun and the actions we're announcing today. On an annual basis going forward, the total reductions and operating expense and cost of sales is expected to be $60 million to $80 million. Alex will provide more details on these charges and associated savings. 
While this decision -- these decisions are difficult for part of our organization, these actions will best position First Solar to increase its competitive position over the next several years. We are excited about the potential of our Series 5 and Series 6 technologies and are well positioned with the resources and capabilities necessary to execute on our plans. 
With that, let's return -- let's turn to our results. Our financial results for the quarter were strong with net sales of over $930 million and non-GAAP earnings per share, excluding restructuring charges, of $0.87. These results are underpinned by continued execution across both our module manufacturing and system project portfolio. 
Our module [indiscernible] efficiency is currently running at 16.7%, and we continue to lower our cost per watt. We completed our Silver State South and the [indiscernible] projects in Q2 and are nearing completion of the Stateline project. We recognize significant cost savings on these projects in the quarter as a result of our outstanding execution. Alex will discuss the financial results for the quarter in more detail. 
Moving on to Slide 5, I'll provide an update on our latest bookings activity. In the second quarter, we shipped close to 750 megawatts of modules, bringing our year-to-date total, as of June 30, to 1.6 gigawatts. Against these shipments, we have booked approximately 1.4 gigawatts year-to-date, including the period up to today's call. 
I'll now provide some more details on the approximately 800 megawatts of looking since our last earnings call. In the U.S., we have signed PPAs for 2 projects totaling over 100 megawatts DC -- 180 megawatts DC with a leading Western utility. These projects have CODs in 2019 and 2020, which now brings our total projects with executed PPAs with CODs in 2019 or later to over 1.2 gigawatts DC, which is ideally suited for the competitively advantaged Series 5, Series 6 and MVDC. As evidenced by these bookings, we continue to see many encouraging signs for solar demand over the long-term horizon. 
Beyond these project bookings, we continue to have active discussions with both utilities and C&I customers seeking large-scale solar power supply. The interest in C&I customers is particularly strong with these customers typically looking for renewables to meet up to 100% of their energy supply needs. We see this opportunity as a key market focus and have a dedicated team specifically working with these customers to provide comprehensive solutions that meet their needs. 
In the U.S., we are also encouraged with increasing demand for community solar solutions, a market segment that we continue to view as having tremendous potential to meet residential and customer -- commercial customers' needs at a dramatically lower cost than it cost solar. 
[indiscernible] the growth potential of Community Solar, a third-party research firm recently estimated that community Solar's addressable market is more than 7x as large as rooftop solar. Thus far in 2016, we have booked over 120 megawatts DC of volume that will supply more the 25 different community solar projects across multiple states. Majority of this volume is with a single customer where we continue to see opportunities to collaborate on future community solar projects. An initial 41 megawatts project is underway with [indiscernible] contractor. 
To put the 120 megawatt of bookings in perspective, once this volume has been installed, it will effectively double the amount of cumulative community solar installations in the U.S. We are pleased with the recent progress and continue to work with various customers to capture the growing community solar opportunity in the U.S. 
Elsewhere in the United States, we booked modest supply agreements for over 80 megawatts DC in diverse solar markets such as Idaho and the North Carolina. 
Internationally, we have bookings in India and have been strong with over 280 megawatts DC of new bookings. The volume book was a combination of both module supply agreements and 60 [ph] megawatts AC of PPAs. These latest PPAs bring our current development pipeline in India to 260 megawatts AC. Altogether, we have booked approximately 250 megawatts DC of systems project this quarter with approximately 1/3 of the volume scheduled for 2017 deliveries. 
Relative to our expectations for the 1 gigawatt of systems business in 2017, we have approximately 400 megawatts DC of contracted projects with additional projects added. 
We have visibility to a number of additional potential booking opportunities that we continue to pursue towards the 1 gigawatt totaled. As we bid on future PPAs, we will continue to maintain our discipline and leverage our strengths in bidding opportunities. In situations where we engage early in the process with key partners and leverage the strength of our new Series 5 technology into the offering, we feel that we are extremely competitive. 
In addition to the 800 megawatts of bookings in the past quarter, we have also been awarded opportunities of over 410 megawatts DC, which we expect to convert into bookings during the remainder of this year. 
Firstly, in Zambia, along with our partner, we were awarded 53 megawatts DC power plant, which is expected to deliver the lowest-cost solar electricity in sub-Sahara Africa. The energy density advantage of our CdTe modules is particularly strong in this type of hot and humid climate and allows us to provide extremely competitive solar solutions. The remaining awarded volume of approximately 357 megawatts DC pertains to module supply agreements in France, Israel, India and Thailand. 
In France, we were pleased with the results of the most recent tender process where we're awarded over 100 megawatts of volume. As these awarded projects are converted into bookings, we will discuss them in more detail on future earnings call. 
Moving on Slide 6. Our bookings and expected revenue term stands at $6 billion, a decrease of $900 million from the end of last year. The decrease in expected revenue is a result of the higher mix of module-only business book as compared to a higher mix of system revenue recognized year-to-date. In addition, it's also driven by lower ASPs associated with some of the longer dated PPAs included in our bookings. While ASPs on these longer-dated PPAs are naturally lower than project we are currently in construction -- constructing, there's still an expectation of attractive margins on these projects, given our efficiency in cost road maps discussed at our Analyst Day earlier this year. 
Slide 7 provides an update of potential bookings opportunities, which has grown to 24 megawatts DC, an increase of approximately 700 megawatts from the prior quarter. Our mid to late-stage booking opportunities are 1.8 gigawatts with international opportunities again comprising close to 90% of this number. Note that over 400 megawatts are awarded but not booked volume discussed earlier in this presentation is included in this 1.8 gigawatts. Also, it is important, as the number of third-party modules sales opportunities and our potential bookings number has increased over time, we are beginning to see an increase in the velocity at which these projects can move from early-stage opportunities to confirm booking. For instance, more than half of our bookings during the past quarter were in early-stage opportunities at the time of our Q1 call. 
Turning to Slide 8. North America remains our largest geography at over 40% of the total. We continue to have a diversified geographic mix of potential booking opportunities. The largest region with no increases since the last call were the United States and India, where we saw significant growth and opportunities from the prior quarter. We're encouraged with expanding pipeline in both of these regions given our historical win rate, reflective of our energy density and the mix of system and module sales. 
One last point to keep in mind is the timing of bookings can be very uneven. For example, the first 6 months of the year, our bookings total was only 800 megawatts. However, in the past month alone, we have added close to 600 megawatts. We continue to aggressively pursuing opportunities while working diligently to close those projects nearing the finish line, including the over 400 megawatts AC awarded I previously made, but the timing of when this occurs can be lumpy. 
I'll now turn it over to Alex, who will provide more detail in our second quarter financial results and discuss updated guidance for 2016.

headline: First Solar, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Mark, and good afternoon. I'll begin with some highlights of our operational performance during the past quarter. In Q2, we produced 785 megawatts DC, or an increase of 1% from the prior quarter, resulting from higher margin efficiencies and incre
componenttext:
Thanks, Mark, and good afternoon. I'll begin with some highlights of our operational performance during the past quarter. In Q2, we produced 785 megawatts DC, or an increase of 1% from the prior quarter, resulting from higher margin efficiencies and increased throughput. Compared to the second quarter of 2015, production was 39% higher as a result of higher efficiencies, improved throughput and the addition of new capacity. 
Our [indiscernible] utilization is unchanged at 100% in Q2 versus the prior quarter, but increased by 15 percentage points versus the same period in 2015. The higher year-over-year capacity utilization was due to fewer efficiency upgrade activities in Q2 as we focused on maximizing output to meet demand in the first half of the year. 
The fleet average module conversion efficiency in Q2 was 16.2%, which was unchanged from the prior quarter, but increased 80 basis points year-over-year. Our best line conversion efficiency was also unchanged from Q1 at 16.4%, but increased by 20 basis points compared to the second quarter of 2015. Most recently, our lead line has been running at 16.7% efficiency. And we're encouraged by our progress towards our target of 17% lead line efficiency at the end of the year. 
Turning to Slide 11. I'll discuss the P&L results for the second quarter. Net sales are $934 million for the quarter compared to $848 million in Q1. The sales increase resulted from higher third-party module sales, the sale of our Kingbird project and higher revenue recognition across various systems projects. Partially offsetting the higher sales was lower revenue recognized in the Silver State South and Stateline project, which reached to a near-completion in Q2. The higher module sales were driven by shipments to projects in Dubai and the Southeastern U.S. 
In relation to our Kingbird project, it should be noted that this project sale was structured with a tax equity partner with the residual cash interest sold to 8point3 Energy Partners, which resulted in a different accounting treatment as compared to our historical project sale. As a result of the transaction structure, whereby First Solar provides an indemnity relating to the tax equity structuring, only a portion of the revenue from the transaction was recognized and the entire profit of $20 million has been deferred on the balance sheet. 
If we have been able to recognize the entire transaction in Q2, our gross margin would have been improved by approximately 80 basis points and earnings per share would have increased by approximately 16%. 
It's important to keep in mind that the underlying economic substance of the transaction was very favorable, but on the current real estate accounting, it is not reflected in the current period results. Also, note that all cash related the project sale both from tax equity and 8point3 was received. 
Continuing on [indiscernible] as a percent to total quarterly net sales, our solar power systems revenue, which includes both our EPC revenue and Solar modules use in systems projects, decreased to 83% from 93% in the prior quarter as a result of the higher mix of the module-only sales. Both margin for the quarter was 20% compared to 31% in the first quarter. The decrease in gross margin percentage resulted primarily from the mix of systems projects recognized between the quarters. 
As a reminder, in Q1, we sold an additional interest in the Stateline project, leading to a significantly higher mix of revenues from development projects in Q1. Q2 gross margin was also impacted by an $8.5 million charge associated with the write-down of TetraSun inventory. Adjusted for this item, second quarter gross margin would have improved by approximately 90 basis points. 
Our component segment gross margin decreased slightly to 24% in the second quarter compared to 29% in Q1. The decrease was primarily due to the geographical mix of sales, partially offset by a decrease in our module cost per watt. We're very encouraged by our progress in reducing our module cost per watt through efficiency improvements, increased throughput and bill of material reductions. 
Operating expenses, including restructuring asset impairment charges, were $97 million in Q2, a decrease of $1 million from the prior quarter. The decrease was due to lower employee-related cost, partially offset by higher R&D expenses for development of our Series 5 technology. 
Restructuring and asset impairment charges totaled $86 million in the quarter, primarily related to TetraSun. As indicated in our recent press release, we anticipate total charges of up to $100 million, substantially all of which is expected to be noncash. We expect operating expense savings of $2 million to $4 million this year and $8 million to $10 million on an annual basis going forward and with $9 million for the second quarter or $94 million adjusted for restructuring prior quarter operating income was $165 million. 
Other income was $7 million in the second quarter compared to $36 million in Q1. The current quarter income was primarily related to a reversal of outstanding contingent consideration associated with the TetraSun acquisition. 
Other income in the prior quarter was primarily due to a $38 million gain from the sale of rebalancing certain restricted investments associated with our modular end-of-life program. 
Tax expense for Q2 was $9 million and the effective tax rate was unusually high due to the impact of restructuring. Adjusted for the restructuring and asset impairment charges, the tax rate for the quarter would be more in line with the full year guidance tax range. Also note that while not in our Q2 results, during July, we received a favorable ruling from a foreign tax authority, which will result in a tax benefit of $35 million in our Q3 results. 
Q2 earnings were $0.13 per fully diluted share on a GAAP basis and $0.87 from a non-GAAP basis. This compares to earnings of $1.66 in the prior quarter. The non-GAAP EPS does not include the $0.16 of deferred Kingbird earnings. Please refer to the appendix of the earnings presentation for the GAAP to non-GAAP EPS reconciliation. 
Nonrecurring charges aside, which were primarily from TetraSun, Q2 was another strong quarter of financial performance, and we're pleased with our progress in the first half of the year. 
Continuing on Slide 12, I'll discuss select balance sheet items and summary cash flow information. Cash and marketable securities decreased $213 million to an ending balance of $1.7 billion. Our net cash position also decreased to $1.4 billion. Cash decreased from the prior quarter due to ongoing construction of projects on balance sheet, capital expenditures and debt repayments. 
For the quarter, net working capital, including the change in noncurrent project assets and excluding cash and marketable securities, was virtually unchanged. The decrease in project-related assets due to the sale of Kingbird and reclassification of certain projects in Chile and India to the Solar power systems was largely offset by an increase in unbilled AR. The Luz del Norte project was reclassified as it is in place and service, and we anticipate holding the asset for several years, pending transmission operators in Chile. The increase in unbilled AR is expected to decline in Q3 as billing milestones are reached. 
Total debt decreased $66 million from the prior quarter, $233 million, primarily due to the $70 million repayment of the remaining balance on our Malaysia debt facilities. The remaining debts outstanding is comprised of $163 million of limited or nonrecourse project level debt and $70 million of recourse project level debt, the majority of which is a short-term VAT loan associated with our Luz del Norte asset. 
Cash flows used in operations was $75 million compared to cash flows from operations of $50 million in the first quarter. Free cash flow is negative $140 million compared to positive free cash flow of $13 million last quarter. Capital expenditures were $78 million as compared to $52 million in the prior quarter, as we increased investments in our Series 5 technology. Depreciation for the quarter was $53 million or approximately $2 million lower than the prior quarter. 
Before turning to our updated guidance for the year, we summarized on Slide 13 the expected impact of restructuring charges and the associated future benefits from these actions. 
Firstly, as indicated, the total expected charges associated with both the TetraSun and other restructuring announcement is between $105 million and $120 million, the majority of which is noncash. Up to $90 million to $100 million of TetraSun charges we incurred approximately $86 million in Q2 with remainder expected to be incurred in the second half of 2016. The charges associated with our EPC and skytron restructuring are expected to be in a range of $15 million to $20 million and expected to occur primarily in the third and fourth quarters. Going forward, we expect total annual savings related to these actions of $60 million to $80 million, of which $55 million to $65 million are cash savings. annualized OpEx savings associated with these actions are expected to be between $35 million and $45 million. Note that due to the timing of restructuring, we expect limited OpEx savings in 2016. 
Turning to Slide 14, I'll now discuss the updates of our full year 2016 guidance. Overall, the changes to our full year non-GAAP guidance, which excludes restructuring, are relatively minor. While the first half of the year results have been strong, we continue to take a measured approach to guidance for the time being, given uncertainties in the second half of the year. In particular, we anticipate closing the sale of the Moapa asset, our California flat asset and our remaining 34% interest in the Stateline asset. As we progress further into the third quarter, we'll have greater visibility into these various projects sales dynamic. 
Relative to Stateline, our guidance assumption continues to anticipate dropping our remaining 34% interest in the project to 8point3, subject to market conditions. To the extent that we do sell all 34% of our interest in 2016, this would likely result in earnings above the midpoint of our guidance. We will also continue to evaluate the potential to sell a portion of our remaining interest in the Stateline in 2017, dependent upon developments in our drilling business in the second half of the year as well as based on market conditions relating to 8point3. 
Turning to our guidance ranges. Our net sales forecast is unchanged at $3.8 billion to $4 billion. We're bringing up the low end of our gross margin guidance to a revised range of 18.5% and 19% compared to the prior range of 18% to 19%. This update is a result of the significant project cost savings achieved in the second quarter. Note that as previously discussed, the net sales range in gross margin guidance include only a portion of the revenue and none of the deferred profit from the Kingbird sale. Our GAAP operating expenses are projected in the range of $485 million to $520 million for the year. This includes the $105 million to $120 million of restructuring associated charges. 
Our non-GAAP operating expense guidance, excluding those restructuring and asset impairment charges, is unchanged at $380 million to $400 million. We're leaving the range unchanged as 2015 OpEx reductions are expected to be limited given the timing of the restructuring and are offset by earlier-than-planned production start-up expenses in the Series 5 acceleration and from the incremental R&D for Series 6. Improvement in the gross margin does not flow through to the low end of our non-GAAP operating income guidance, which has been raised to $310 million. The non-GAAP effective tax rate is expected to be in the range of 16% to 18%. This projected tax range excludes the impact of all restructuring actions and also excludes the impact of the $35 million tax benefit mentioned previously. 
Moving onto EPS guidance. On a GAAP basis, we expect earnings in the range of $3.65 to $3.90, excluding restructuring charges, the low end of our non-GAAP EPS guidance is range of $4.20, with the upper bound unchanged at $4.50. The impact to EPS from the expected sale of our remaining interest in Stateline and [indiscernible] share of 8point3's earnings remains unchanged at approximately $145 million, net of tax.  Additionally, approximately $0.20 of other income, net of tax, is included in the earnings guidance range from the previously discussed Q1 sale of the restricted investments. Also, keep in mind that the EPS guidance does not include the $0.16 of deferred Kingbird earnings. The distribution of earnings for the remainder of the year is anticipated to be slightly more weighted towards the fourth quarter due to the timing of expected project sales. 
Operating cash flow has been reduced to $500 million to $650 million from the prior range of $500 million to $700 million, reflecting the expected impact of cash restructuring charges. Again, the operating cash flow range does not include approximately $320 million from the expected sale of the remaining interest in Stateline, which we expect to treat as an investing cash flow. 
Our capital expenses guidance has been revised to a range of $275 million to $325 million from the previous range of $300 million to $400 million, reflecting a change in timing of expected spend. Adjustment to timing has no impact in our planned efficiency road map in Series 5 product launch. The net results of these changes leads our net cash balance unchanged at $1.9 billion to $2.2 billion. 
Turning to Slide 15. I'll now summarize our progress during the past quarter. Firstly, our financial results for the second quarter was strong with revenue of $934 million and non-GAAP EPS of $0.87. We updated our 2016 non-GAAP earnings guidance range to $4.20 to $4.50. Our technology performance is progressing towards the goal we outlined in our April Analyst Day with a best line efficiently -- efficiency currently running at 16.7%. And our year-to-date bookings are now 1.4 gigawatts with over 800 megawatts booked since our last earnings call. The number of potential bookings opportunities continues to grow and are now over 24 gigawatts. 
With this, we conclude our prepared remarks and open the call for questions. Operator?

headline: First Solar, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 03, 2016

headline: First Solar, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Mark, can you maybe talk about the profitability of the bookings that you're seeing right now, especially in markets like India? And can you just provide how we should think about capacity especially as you get into 2017?
componenttext: Mark, can you maybe talk about the profitability of the bookings that you're seeing right now, especially in markets like India? And can you just provide how we should think about capacity especially as you get into 2017?

headline: First Solar, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. I guess, just -- general color on the profitability and bookings. We're still very pleased with the margin realization that we're capturing. We are being very disciplined, though, engaging and making sure that we're capturing full value of our techno
componenttext: Yes. I guess, just -- general color on the profitability and bookings. We're still very pleased with the margin realization that we're capturing. We are being very disciplined, though, engaging and making sure that we're capturing full value of our technology. So if you use India as an example, it's a market that our technology is competitively advantaged. It's a hot, humid climate. We have a superior response in the [indiscernible] and energy advantage over crystalline. Plus, it's mainly [indiscernible] structures in India, which is again more advantaged for our Series 4 product than, say, a tracker solution. Plus, we have a number of self-developed products in India. And the returns of what we're capturing [indiscernible] those projects are in line with probably what we would normally expect, and even in some cases, the upper end of our expectation. We've been very pleased with the out-performance of the asset. Having said that, is the market becoming more competitive? I mean, it clearly is. We're seeing a lot of very aggressive pricing behavior in the market, whether it's at the PPA level or whether it's the module level. And that's why we have to be disciplined and selective in engaging with customers and developing relationships to ensure we can catch the whole value of the offers and the value creation that we provide to our partners and customers. So we are being disciplined in that regard, and we're seeing a very more aggressive market environment. There's no doubt about that. And that's also informed our view around capacity expansion and why we are being disciplined as we think about [indiscernible] capacity and will -- as we communicated in the prepared remarks, that will continue that as we move forward. As it relates to near term, our focus is converting all of our capacity into Series 5. So we want all our Series 4 product into Series 5 as quickly as possible. And our current time line would indicate that that would happen in the end of 2017. We'll continue then also to validate the business case around Series 6. And as we get more and more -- and have a better understanding [indiscernible] of the current views around Series 6, we'll start to think about how to add capacity and the associated timing around that. I would say, for now, again, near-term focus to moving Series 4 to Series 5. As we get better information and validate the Series 6, that will kind of determine the timing when we kind of start adding capacity.

componenttext: I got 2. As we look to next year, is that a valid range for us to think about as of this year what you guys talked about as your target margin? And I guess as you look at projects, like Moapa, which you can move around a little bit, what type of -- and I think you guys already said that you're at the high end of the guidance, if everything goes okay. So it seems like there's some flexibility into next year as well. So how do you guys think about that, about 2017, and being able to move projects into that if it -- you don't need to finish them this year as well as the margin question?

headline: First Solar, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: I'll do the margin question. I'll let Alex take the question around thinking timing of activities between '17 and '16. As it relates to margin realization, similarly, I think, highlighted in the Analyst Day, and especially when you start looking at our co
componenttext: I'll do the margin question. I'll let Alex take the question around thinking timing of activities between '17 and '16. As it relates to margin realization, similarly, I think, highlighted in the Analyst Day, and especially when you start looking at our contract pipeline, in particular, the margin profile, it will start on the lower end of the range in '17 and then continue to improve as we move through the balance of this decade, primarily because as we transition into Series 5, it's a much more competitive product. And it will -- what we look at right now for Series 5 capacity in 2017, it's probably going to be right around 1 gigawatt, which means we have about 2 gigawatts of Series 4 product that we're going to have to sell through. We also indicated the comments today that the value of that delta and form factor as it relates to lower labor costs, fewer connectors, better water management, better [indiscernible] is worth over 100 basis points of equivalent efficiency. So what you should think about is our margin profile in '17 is going to be on the lower end. It's mainly because 2/3 of our production volume is still going to be Series 4. As we transition that into Series 5, and then really get to position of pull that form factor and really capturing full value of our energy advantages, you'll see margin expansion as we go into '18, '19 and '20.

headline: First Solar, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 03, 2016

componenttext: Yes. And we talked about the project, it relates to Cal flats, Moapa and then our residual interest in the [indiscernible] asset. We would expect to complete the sale of the Cal flats asset in either late Q3 or early Q4 and then Moapa in Q4 this year. We've guided to selling our remaining 34% interest in Stateline this year, and that's [indiscernible] our base case. It's a long way to Moapa and Cal flats [indiscernible] significant uncertainty around the structure and the ultimate value of the sales. In terms of our guidance, we're conservative as we continue to develop structures. Stateline sale is really dependent on the other 2 deals as well as market conditions relating to the yield curve. So we'll make that decision in Q3 or Q4. We do have the flexibility with Stateline to push some of that into '17, if needed.

componenttextpreview: So relative to the contract in our system business pipeline for 2017 [indiscernible] India [indiscernible] to 100 megawatts DC, we have about 400 megawatts of systems business already positioned for 2017. We have a pipeline that will move us towards closi
componenttext: So relative to the contract in our system business pipeline for 2017 [indiscernible] India [indiscernible] to 100 megawatts DC, we have about 400 megawatts of systems business already positioned for 2017. We have a pipeline that will move us towards closing that out and getting 2 gigawatt expectation for 2017. That's another 600 megawatts or so. We're still working through those. There are a couple in there that I would say that -- not around the economics. Economics are very compelling. There's some issues around structuring of the PPAs and overall bankability of those PPAs that [indiscernible] some of these are international markets where for us China work through and making sure they could some fashionable and back about its other some challenges in that regard. But I would say, there's pipeline of projects that would enable us to get to our goal of having 1 gigabyte of systems business in 2017. The other aspect that we continue to be very mindful of very disciplined on is making sure that we get proper return on capital given the risk profile of doing international development business, right? In some markets pricing, very aggressive. have to be careful in that regard. So we'll be balanced, making sure the return on capital is just as commensurate with the underlying risk associated with those opportunities. But what I would say in navigate, we're still very happy with the robustness of our pipeline to get to our goal next year of 1 gigawatts of systems business. On the Stateline discussion, I'll take that one of [indiscernible] Alex take the question on Moapa. When you get the Q, which will be available tomorrow, see, think we'll see effectively, 96% or somewhere in the upper 90s as the Stateline has been completed through the second quarter. So the vast majority of the revenue that was related to the sale of the [indiscernible] has now been recognized through Q2. We have about 4% of that [indiscernible] and the project will achieve DOD in the third quarter.

componenttext: Mark, in the prepared remarks, you talked about how the expected revenue per expected module shipment, It's coming down a little bit, owing to the shift towards longer-dated PPAs. Is that a trend? And is a trend that in any way relates to the your customers' awareness of your product transition?

headline: First Solar, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: I don't -- clearly, it's a trend. We see prices are coming down. You can see that each and every day when somebody announces a new PPA price wherever that may be around the world and PPA prices have become pretty competitive in a number of markets. Some o
componenttext: I don't -- clearly, it's a trend. We see prices are coming down. You can see that each and every day when somebody announces a new PPA price wherever that may be around the world and PPA prices have become pretty competitive in a number of markets. Some of those, I would argue, some cases, it's questionable whether or not they'll be viable or able to be achieved. But there's a pretty long runway to deliver some of those assets. It was a lot into 2019, 2020 time frame or potentially later than that. So clearly, PPA prices have come down. I don't know if it's directly related to -- I wouldn't sort of position is being directly related to our advantages in our advancements in our road map and our form factor and efficiency. The other day, we compete against [indiscernible] and so it's really relevant to the alternate technology that's in the marketplace. To the extent that we create separation relative to [indiscernible] silicate, [indiscernible] back to First Solar. I would also say that there is a very strong bias in the marketplace for more and more customers and developers and partners coming to First Solar first. We've got a number of parties who historically, over the years, had moved away from First Solar that are coming back to First Solar. And we've also got a number of other partners that are starting to come to discussions with First Solar that we sort of -- we never had conversations with. And they do think that is related to our road map and our technology and understanding where for sellers going to go long term with our capability, not only on the [indiscernible] as indicated before, with MVDC any advantages that creates for the balance of system costs and its general earnings around optimization and management. A lot of people are looking to drive down a lot of cost. Getting more and more into from other parties want to be doing more business with First Solar. So clearly, the trend is lower PPA. But not to the extent that where they're looking for the PPA pricing is going, that I'm concerned relative to what we can personally do with our overall cost reduction road map. I just said is relevant data point. It's [indiscernible] alone year-on-year, a reduction on our module cost has been in the mid to upper teens. So in the last 12 months, we've taken mid to upper teens type of cost out of our module, which is extremely impactful and competitive and also creates an opportunity to have robust margins against the contracted pipeline that would be great.

componenttext: I think you touched on this in part already, but I want to ask a more pointed question. Modulate fees globally are falling sharply and overcapacity issues. [indiscernible] downside really started in [indiscernible] July. How is this impacting your module-only in Module Plus business? headline: First Solar, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, like I mentioned previously, Phil, our volume right now for Series 5 in 2017 will be about 1 gigawatts. So about 1/3 of our production will be Series 5. So there'll still be a meaningful amount of Series 4 product that we'll obviously have to sell th
componenttext: Yes, like I mentioned previously, Phil, our volume right now for Series 5 in 2017 will be about 1 gigawatts. So about 1/3 of our production will be Series 5. So there'll still be a meaningful amount of Series 4 product that we'll obviously have to sell through into next year. Some of that is already contracted. But there is more volume that we have to make sure that we sell through in that regard. You're right. Module pricing has become more competitive. We are still able to command a premium for our technology. That's why we try to focus on markets where we're more significantly advanced. I mean, even referenced in our prepared remarks, and [indiscernible] are, right? So there's an opportunity in Zambia for 50 [ph] megawatts. It's a hot, humid climate, which is advantage for our technology. So what we're doing globally is looking at pockets of strength. We're trying to manage with constraining ourself on available capacity, at least at this point in time, especially as it relates to Series 4. We're looking for pockets of strength where we can sell through and capture highest margin opportunity in [indiscernible] that we have relative to what's going on in the marketplace. But we're very well aware of the how [indiscernible] pricing has become.

headline: First Solar, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: So -- I don't know -- I'll skip that question, what inning are we in? I don't know. This industry is so dynamic and can change so quickly be able to articulate and have a well-thought-out view of what inning is. It's difficult because it can change. The g
componenttext: So -- I don't know -- I'll skip that question, what inning are we in? I don't know. This industry is so dynamic and can change so quickly be able to articulate and have a well-thought-out view of what inning is. It's difficult because it can change. The game change very quickly and events can happen very quickly that it becomes disruptive or undermined or events could happen that become very positive. And clearly, there is that the positive side there, the clear understanding globally of kind of the [indiscernible] solar and solar many different markets and that's driving the demand will sell the end it's obviously very encouraging. This also -- the side of that is there is quite a bit of capacity that is being added -- plan to be at added, made as a better way to say that. That could change very quickly as well. I mean, as people think about the market opportunities and what they're willing to sell through and what is sustainable, the plan announcement that have been communicated may or may not happen. I mean there's still a lot of uncertainty whether or not that supply comes to market or not. So I don't want to get into the analogy of an inning because it's very, very difficult from that standpoint.

headline: First Solar, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: On the margins piece, I'd say 2017 is still pretty uncertain, so we'll have more clarity at the end of the year on the guidance call. What I would say, though, is that, always know that '17 would be a challenging year, especially as we saw margins decline
componenttext: On the margins piece, I'd say 2017 is still pretty uncertain, so we'll have more clarity at the end of the year on the guidance call. What I would say, though, is that, always know that '17 would be a challenging year, especially as we saw margins declined from our [indiscernible] legacy contract [indiscernible] rolled off. That expansion extension in 2016 came too late to influence 2017. That's why we think it's clearly important that we've transition towards higher module business in '17 but also the product from Series 4 to Series 5. Other thing I'd refer you back to is the Analyst Day when we talked about what our long-term contracted pipeline looks like. Back then we spoke about having over 2.5 gigawatts of contracted asses after 2017 with north of $1 billion of contracted margins entitlement. But think if you look at that, combine that with -- even without capacity expansion of another 7 or so gigawatts of modules to sell, would expect some of that volume to be incremental systems as well as modules, you combine that with [indiscernible] production road map OpEx coming down, I think we look to see beyond '17 having acceptable and robust margins across the new products. '17 itself is somewhat opaque today and will give better guidance about that towards the end of the year.

componenttext: I have 3 of them here. First, in 2017, are you still comfortable with the 1 gigawatts system business? I guess this morning, Dominion came out and doubled their outlook for Solar in '17 and Georgia Power clearly with their 1.6 gigawatt business. I guess, I'm trying to understand your comfort level on the 1 gigawatts if that's increased or decreased relative to Q1 view. That's the first question. Second question, can you just flesh out maybe the low end of margin guidance? Just -- there's a few ranges at Analyst Day. I'm curious. Third point, the component gross margins of 24%, I guess, more of an accounting question. But is that driven by spot market pricing or the pricing locked in during contracting?

headline: First Solar, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. So on the gigawatt for '17, like before, 400 megawatts right now, you're asking me the other 600, there's pretty high confidence on 300 and 600. The other 600 -- the other 300, I would say, there's still a number of moving pieces and announced a litt
componenttext: Yes. So on the gigawatt for '17, like before, 400 megawatts right now, you're asking me the other 600, there's pretty high confidence on 300 and 600. The other 600 -- the other 300, I would say, there's still a number of moving pieces and announced a little recently -- our people are thinking about especially in the U.S, opportunity to bring here in '17 gets more encouraging. As look at some of these international opportunities and especially the challenges in some cases to the PPAs are indicated to get them to be finance about. That's sort of the sways the other way. But I would say on balance, we feel that we will get to -- whether it's 850 or 900, it's going to be within a ZIP Code going to be close to that 1 gigawatts of volumes, just for next year. So level of comfort from that standpoint. On the margin guidance, I think the best way to handle it as Alex already said, we're not going to get into the  the specifics of that right now. There's still many moving pieces that we would rather wait until we do our guidance call in December. And what I would offer [indiscernible] point to you is that that we view that we communicate in December, I don't think we should look at it as a discrete data point as indicative of long-term earnings potential for First Solar. '17 margin profile, especially on indicated with Series 4, still being a prominent product in our platform, it's going to drive a little bit of margin pressure. There's no doubt about that. But that's a temporary issue that corrects itself in the second half of '17 and then just completely fixed by the end of '17 where we got form factor that's consistent with [indiscernible] and driving towards a 390-watt panel that with all of the energy advantages that we talked about around CdTe. So when you look at it [indiscernible] and we feel very confident about what we're going with our technology and ultimately the products. Around the component gross margin, there's an element of spot and it's also the -- it's an indication of contracted volume. So it's a combination of the 2. As we indicated this quarter, as an example, over half of our bookings that we recorded of our 800 megawatts or so were not in our late-stage development pipeline, which means that those were transaction since the last earnings call that we've gone out and we've negotiated around pricing in a very short period of time and then close this orders and a high percentage of that volume will shift this year and those margins that will be realized against the shipments will be in line with what were currently reflecting in our components segments today. And as they also indicated, if you just look at our module cost delta, year-on-year, we seen high teens, upper teens cost reduction when our module, just in the last 12 months. And maybe team continues to make tremendous progress in that side of the house. So we're able to as best we can, sort of a manage that price cost battle. But we also doing away with regard to be selective were selling through a to make sure we were targeting market so that we get the highest value of our products.

componenttext: So on the Series 5 comment and impact to cash balance, the think -- I think you also other think about perhaps Series 5 it's really relatively CapEx-light relative to -- if when to start any new greenfield, also taking some magnitude [indiscernible] platform and converting it into a different product, right, optimized around a lot of management and some other things along those lines. And so it's not really a significant CapEx. We're going to finish this year somewhere around $2 billion of cash as we exit the year. Series 5 of itself is not going to drive a significant delta to that number as we deploy that capacity or conversion of product Series 4 to Series 5 product in 2017. I'm not sure I got your last question. Repeat your last question?
