headline: First Solar, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: Good afternoon, everyone, and welcome to First Solar's Third Quarter 2016 Earnings Call. This call is being webcast live on the Investors section of First Solar's website at firstsolar.com. [Operator Instructions] As a reminder, today's call is being reco
componenttext:
Good afternoon, everyone, and welcome to First Solar's Third Quarter 2016 Earnings Call. This call is being webcast live on the Investors section of First Solar's website at firstsolar.com. [Operator Instructions] As a reminder, today's call is being recorded. 
I would now like to turn the call over to Steve Haymore  from First Solar's Investor Relations. Mr. Haymore, you may begin.

headline: First Solar, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thank you. Good afternoon, everyone, and thank you for joining us. Today, the company issued a press release announcing its financial results for the third quarter of 2016. A copy of the press release and the presentation are available on the Investors se
componenttext:
Thank you. Good afternoon, everyone, and thank you for joining us. Today, the company issued a press release announcing its financial results for the third quarter of 2016. A copy of the press release and the presentation are available on the Investors section of First Solar's website at firstsolar.com. 
With me today are Mark Widmar, Chief Executive Officer; and Alex Bradley, Chief Financial Officer. Mark will provide a business and technology update, then Alex will discuss our third quarter financial results and provide updated guidance for 2016. We will then open up the call for questions. 
Most of the financial numbers reported and discussed on today's call are based on U.S. generally accepted accounting principles. In a few cases where we report non-GAAP measures, such as free cash flow or non-GAAP EPS, we have reconciled the non-GAAP measures and the corresponding GAAP measures at the back of the presentation. 
Please note this call will include forward-looking statements that involve risks and uncertainties that could cause actual results to differ materially from management's current expectations. We encourage you to review the safe harbor statements contained in today's press release and presentation for a more complete description. 
It is now my pleasure to introduce Mark Widmar, Chief Executive Officer. Mark?

headline: First Solar, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Steve. Good afternoon, and thank you for joining us today. We had another good quarter of financial results in Q3, with net sales of $688 million and an earnings per share, excluding restructuring charges and a foreign tax benefit, of $1.22. We co
componenttext:
Thanks, Steve. Good afternoon, and thank you for joining us today. We had another good quarter of financial results in Q3, with net sales of $688 million and an earnings per share, excluding restructuring charges and a foreign tax benefit, of $1.22. We continue to push forward on our technology road map, with our best line efficiency exiting the third quarter almost touching 17% at 16.9% efficiency. Our project execution was also strong as we continued construction on multiple utility-scale solar projects and continue to realize significant BoS savings. 
Despite the results of the past quarter, the rapidly evolving market pricing environment, as shown on Slide 5 -- 4, excuse me, present significant challenges to the upcoming year. While we will not be discussing our 2017 outlook on today's call, it is important to understand the dramatic pricing declines that the industry is currently experiencing and how we intend to respond. 
As we highlighted on our Q2 earnings call, we saw the module and PPA pricing environment that time as increasingly aggressive and challenging. However, the impact of the lower second half 2016 installs in China were only just becoming evident, and the weeks since that call, we've seen other module manufacturers continue to bring online new capacity in the face of the demand dropoff in China. As a result of the oversupply and growing inventories, module pricing has declined at a dramatic rate in the third quarter. 
Since quarter end, there has been some signs of potential stabilization as wafer and self-spot prices first leveled off then increased slightly. In addition, module AFPs have leveled off, perhaps finding the near-term floor as manufacturers clear inventory. 
As we said consistently and reiterated on our Q1 2016 earnings call, when an oversupply situation exists, our strategy is to take a disciplined approach to the market. This means that we may walk away from module supply opportunity if the economics do not make sense for us. 
During the past quarter, challenging pricing conditions dictated that in certain situations we needed to apply this strategy, which has impacted our near-term booking. But we continue to view the strategy as the most sensible long-term approach. In these types of oversupply situations, we also will look very closely at our module manufacturing capacity. Our goal is not to push supply into a saturated and margin-challenged market, but rather to balance production to meet demand. 
As a result of this strategy in current market conditions, we have begun the process of evaluating our module capacity for next year. Mostly connected to any capacity decisions is the timing of our Series 5 and Series 6 product transitions. In regard to Series 5, we are looking very hard at the cost structure and how to bring the module cost brought down further in this competitive environment. In terms of our Series 6 product, we have dedicated significant resources to focus on how to accelerate the road map and product availability. 
In the current ASP environment, without further cost reduction, Series 4 and Series 5 margins may be challenged. We expect that our Series 6 module would be our most competitive product and enable us to capture greater gross margin per watt. Beyond both pricing and capacity decisions, we are also focused on identifying ways to improve our operating expense profile, which will improve our competitiveness. 
We are progressing in our valuation of each of these initiatives. However, any final decisions are subject to our normal board review process. We will hold a separate call on November 16 to discuss the 2017 outlook and provide further update at that time. 
Turning to Slide 5. I'll provide an update on bookings activity since our last earnings call. As we announced in our recent press release, we have signed a PPA of up to 160 megawatts with MCE, a leading community choice aggregator in California. While we are only including 40 megawatts in our bookings number this quarter, we have an option to expand the project to a total of 160 megawatts, subject to satisfaction of certain PPA contract conditions and based on the load increase high-potential MCE expansion. Construction on the project is anticipated to begin in 2019, with commissioning expected in 2020. 
CCAs are increasingly important providers of electricity to customers, both in California and a growing number of other states. CCAs offer their customers the benefit of local control, competitive power rates and access to a higher mix of renewable energy. MCE provides power to over 250,000 customers in California. And with the addition of other entrants in the CCA market in the coming months, the total CCA customer base in the state is expected to grow to approximately 1 million customers. We're excited to bring this -- to begin a new association with MCE and help make affordable clean power even more accessible. 
The growth of CCAs across the nation also mirrors the growth of community solar that is occurring across the United States. As we've highlighted last quarter, we have booked over 120 megawatts DC of module supply to community solar projects so far this year. These projects are only part of the rapid growth that is continuing in the community solar space across the United States. 
While the initial growth in community solar has been specific to certain states, the momentum continues to build. There are now community solar projects in 24 states, and 20 additional states are in the process of enacting community solar policies. In 2016 alone, 19 new utilities have started community solar programs. We continue to work closely with Clean Energy Collective and other community solar providers to identify new opportunities to facilitate market growth. 
Highlighting the growing scale of community solar projects, South Carolina Electric and Gas recently selected CEC to develop, construct and operate a 60-megawatt portfolio project. With a much lower cost than rooftop solar and the opportunity to rate base projects in certain situations, community solar is a utility-friendly model that is expected to grow substantially in coming years. 
Returning to the current quarter. We had module-only bookings of over 200 megawatts since our last call, bringing the total booking since the last call to nearly 250 megawatts. The largest of these module bookings, approximately 100 megawatts, was to supply our customer-awarded volume under the most recent French tender. Module shipments timing will be late Q4 2016 and into 2017. 
Outside the volume in France, we are seeing increasing geographical diversity in our module-only opportunities. Besides the U.S., we have bookings in Thailand, various countries across Asia and Latin America. 
As we look forward, we continue to see a number of opportunities that we anticipate will lead to growth -- to stronger module bookings in the next several months. 
As highlighted last quarter, there are a number of awarded projects which we have not yet converted to bookings. At this point, we have converted over 160 megawatts of these projects into bookings, and they are reflected in today's number, with additional 105 megawatts DC of opportunities related to projects awarded under the recent ARENA large-scale solar grant in Australia are awarded, but not booked volume, now stands at approximately 270 megawatts. As a highlight, the ARENA volume includes our first self-developed project in Australia. Keep in mind, this awarded volume is not reflected in Slides 5 and 6. 
Also not included in the bookings number are a number of O&M contracts which we have signed this year. 
With over 5 gigawatts of generation capacity in operation and more than 7 gigawatts of contracting capacity, First Solar is the recognized industry leader in providing O&M services for utility-scale solar power plants. With a complete end-to-end solution and a fleet availability of 99.6%, First Solar offers customers the compelling combination of expertise and proven performance. 
Our O&M business continues to grow, not only by securing contracts and projects where we perform the EPC, but also through third-party contracts. Year-to-date, we have signed 930 megawatts of third-party O&M agreements. In addition to signing agreements with existing customers, these recent bookings also include 6 new third-party customers. Beyond these third-party bookings, we have contracted over 540 megawatts of additional volume for projects we have constructed, bringing the total year-to-date O&M bookings to nearly 1.5 gigawatts. 
With additional advance-stage opportunity that is currently under negotiation, bookings could reach over 1.8 gigawatts by year end. 
Overall, we are pleased with the progress we are making in third-party O&M business and the stable revenue and earnings it provides. 
The lower module and system bookings this past quarter are primarily a result of the current module ASP and PPA pricing environment. Our strategy has been to pursue opportunities in markets where we can best leverage the energy over the advantage of our technology while maintaining discipline around returns. However, the willingness of other module manufacturers to continue ramping capacity and selling modules at very aggressive ASPs presents near-term challenges. The decline in ASP environment also led to some instances where customers have delayed signing agreements in hope of further pricing declines. While achieving a 1:1 book-to-bill ratio this year will be challenging, as we look to the fourth quarter, we have a number of bookings opportunities that we believe we are well positioned despite the current market environment. 
Turning to Slide 7. I'll provide an update on our potential bookings opportunities, which has grown to over 25.4 gigawatts DC, an increase of approximately 1.4 gigawatts from the prior quarter. Our mid-to-late stage bookings opportunities are 1.1 gigawatts with the awarded volume discussed earlier included in this total. Approximately 1/3 of the late-stage opportunities are systems projects with the balance comprised of the module-only sales. The reduction in the mid-to-late stage opportunities since last quarter was approximately 700 megawatts. Of this amount, over 150 megawatts were due to projects that converted in bookings, another 350 megawatts of systems project opportunities were closed in both Egypt and South Africa due to uncertain market conditions in both countries. The remaining decrease was due to projects lost to aggressive pricing terms. In these situations, we chose to remain disciplined and not to match uneconomic pricing. 
The growth in the overall potential bookings opportunities is primarily driven by new project development opportunities, which we expect to be delivered in 2018 and beyond. The long-term demand driver for solar continues to be strong, and we are working actively to position ourselves to meet the long-term demand. 
On Slide 8, we have updated the geographic mix of our potential bookings. The increase in our potential bookings opportunities is primarily driven by new opportunities in the United States. One of the factors driving an increase in the United States potential bookings is the increase from C&I customers. This continues to develop into a promising utility-scale solar market that we feel we are well positioned to be successful in the upcoming years. Corporations globally have announced plans for renewal procurement that collectively total into tens of gigawatts. We currently have more than 2 gigawatts of active offers in progress today with C&I customers. Most of these projects are still early stage and have longer-dated CODs, but they represent another encouraging demand driver for the long-term growth of solar. One of the factors that provides First Solar an advantage in this market space is the sensitivity C&I customers have to reputational risk. They don't want to see a project fail or not be delivered. With our financial strength and our development track record, we are well positioned to meet their needs. 
Lastly, as announced recently, Alex Bradley has been appointed our new Chief Financial Officer. As you're aware, Alex has been serving as our interim CFO since July and has made a seamless transition from his previous responsibility as head of project finance and treasury. During his time at First Solar, Alex has led or supported the financing and sale of almost all of our utility-scale solar projects. The experience and skill Alex brings into this role will be a tremendous benefit to First Solar and its shareholders. Alex will now provide more detail on the third quarter financial results and discuss updated guidance for 2016.

headline: First Solar, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Mark. Before going into the quarter results, I want to express my excitement on the opportunity to take on the role as CFO of First Solar. Since I joined the company in 2008, the solar industry has changed enormously, and it continues to evolve at
componenttext:
Thanks, Mark. Before going into the quarter results, I want to express my excitement on the opportunity to take on the role as CFO of First Solar. Since I joined the company in 2008, the solar industry has changed enormously, and it continues to evolve at a rapid pace. First Solar's unique technology advantages and financial strength position the company for long-term success, and I look forward to the opportunities that lie ahead for us. 
Turning to the quarter. I'll start on Slide 11 with some operational highlights. We produced 779 megawatts DC in the third quarter, a decrease of 1% from the prior quarter. The slight decrease is due to an increase in upgrade activities across the fleet, partially offset by higher fleet efficiency. Relative to the third quarter of 2015, production was 19% higher as a result of higher module efficiency, increased capacity utilization and the addition of new capacity. 
[indiscernible] utilization was 97% in Q3, a decrease of 3 percentage points from the prior quarter. The lower utilization was also a result of increasing fleet upgrade activities. As compared to third quarter of 2015, capacity utilization increased by 3 percentage points. 
Fleet average module conversion efficiency increased to 16.5%, a 30 basis point increase quarter-over-quarter and a 70 basis point increase year-over-year. Module conversion efficiency on our best line averaged 16.6% [ph] in Q3. As Mark noted, [indiscernible] exited the quarter at 16.9%, highlighting the impact of recent improvement programs [indiscernible] 
Next on Slide 12, I'll discuss the P&L results for the third quarter. Net sales of $688 million, a decrease of $246 million compared to the prior quarter. The sales decrease resulted from lower systems revenue recognition on our Astoria [indiscernible] Kingbird and other projects. The lower systems revenues partially offset by an increase in module-only sales. As a percentage of total cautionary net sales, our solar power systems revenue, which includes both our EPC revenue and solar modules use in systems projects, decreased to 69% from 83% in the prior quarter as a result of the high mix of module-only sales. 
Gross margin for the quarter was 27% compared to 20% in the second quarter. Improvement in gross margin percentage resulted from a higher mix of third-party module sales as well as improved systems module, resulting from project cost reductions. The gross margin of our component segment was 32% in Q3 compared to 24% in Q2. The increase versus the prior quarter is primarily due to lower module cost per watt, improved efficiency and lower inventory write-downs. 
Operating expenses, excluding restructuring and asset impairment charges, were $93 million in Q3, a decrease of $4 million from the prior quarter. Operating expenses decreased primarily due to lower employee-related costs. Restructuring and asset impairment charges of $4 million in the quarter compared to $86 million in Q2. The restructuring charges are related to the actions announced in Q2, including discontinuing our TetraSun product, the disposition of Skytron and EPC reductions. The total charges for all these actions are now expected to be slightly lower in the range of $105 million to $115 million compared to the $105 million to $120 million range we originally anticipated, with most of the impact in 2016. Operating expense savings from these actions is expected to be in the range of $35 million to $45 million per annum. Excluding restructuring-related items, operating income was $93 million for the third quarter compared to $95 million in the prior quarter. The decrease is due to lower revenue, partially offset by higher gross margin percentage and lower operating expenses. 
Other income of $6 million in the third quarter, primarily due to the resolution of outstanding asset with a former customer. Second quarter other income was $7 million, mainly due to reversal of outstanding contingent consideration related to the TetraSun acquisition. 
We had a tax benefit of $51 million in Q3 compared to tax expense of $9 million in the second quarter. As we indicated on our last quarter's call, in July, we received a favorable ruling from the foreign tax authority, which has resulted in a $35 million tax benefit to our Q3 results. Note that for purposes, our full year non-GAAP EPS guidance would exclude this benefit. The third quarter results also include a tax benefit of $13 million associated with the expiration of the statute of limitations on various uncertain tax position. The third quarter earnings were 100 -- $1.49 per fully diluted share on a GAAP basis and $1.22 on non-GAAP basis. This compares to earnings of $0.13 and non-GAAP earnings of $0.87 in the prior quarter. Please refer to the appendix of the earnings presentation for the GAAP to non-GAAP EPS reconciliation. 
Turning to Slide 13. I'll discuss select balance sheet items and cash flow information. Cash and multiple securities increased $423 million to an ending balance of $2.1 billion. Our net cash position decreased slightly to $1.3 billion from $1.4 billion in the prior quarter as a result of continuing to construct certain projects on balance sheet. The increase in cash resulted primarily from borrowing on our revolving credit facility, with ongoing funding of several substantial projects on the balance sheet, the short-term borrowing on the revolver was necessary to fund domestic requirements while complying with certain statutory funding requirements. As we sell the projects we've been constructing on balance sheet, we expect to pay down the revolver in either Q4 of 2016 or Q1 of 2017. 
For the quarter, net working capital, including change in noncurrent project assets and excluding cash and marketable securities, decreased by over $430 million, primarily due to the increase in short-term borrowings. Excluding this item, net working capital would have increased primarily due to the growth in project assets. 
Total debt in the third quarter was $787 million, an increase of $554 million from the prior quarter. And as discussed previously, this increase was primarily due to the borrowing on the revolver. 
Cash flows used in operations were $76 million compared to cash flows used in operations of $75 million in Q2. Free cash flow is negative $132 million compared to negative free cash flow of $139 million last quarter. 
Capital expenditures were $46 million compared to $78 million in the prior quarter, and depreciation for the quarter is $52 million or approximately $1 million lower than the prior quarter. 
I'll now discuss the update to our full year 2016 on Slide 14. Firstly, keep in mind that, as Mark mentioned, we are in the process of evaluating certain decisions related to our production capacity, module product transitions and operating expense rationalization. As a result, our current year of 2016 guidance on a GAAP basis could be subject to change, depending upon the outcome of this process. To the extent that there are any changes to 2016 outlook, these will be provided on the 2017 guidance call on November 16. Also, as we've communicated over the course of the year, we constructed our guidance to account for the factors that could impact the timing of the large and complex project sales included in our forecast. As a result of this approach, we've been able to maintain our earnings per share guidance, even while our net sales guidance has been lowered. These rely [indiscernible] on certain project sales. It's important to keep this context in mind as we discuss the updates. 
Our net sales guidance has been revised to $2.8 billion to $2.9 billion from the prior guidance of $3.8 billion to $4 billion. This change is due to project timing as we now expect to complete the sale of our Moapa and California project in 2017. 
Regarding Moapa, we recently closed tax equity financing for project, received a portion of the cash in Q4. The marketing of the remaining cash equities generated considerable interest and expect that sale to close in Q1 of 2017. 
In relation to our Stateline projects, we've offered our remaining 34% interest to 8point3. The project sale is advancing expected to close by year-end. In the guidance that we provided today, we are including only a portion of the remaining 34% interest in the project, pending the final approval and closing the sale. As previously indicated, to the extent that we do sell the entire remaining interest in 2016, this will likely result in an earnings at or above the high end of the guidance range provided today. As a reminder, the profit from the remaining sale to 8point3 will be reflected below operating income and equity and earnings, and not in revenue and gross margin. 
Resulting from the changes in the timing of project sales, we're updating our gross margin guidance to 25.5% to 26% from 18.5% to 19% previously. The increase in the gross margin percentage is a reflection of both the relatively low gross margin associated with the Moapa and California Flats project we've been pushed out and also a lot of project cost savings achieved in Q3. 
GAAP operating expenses are expected to be in the range of $480 million to $500 million and include $105 million to $115 million of restructuring-related charges. Note that the expected TetraSun charges have been lowered to a range of $90 million to $95 million from the prior range of up to $100 million. 
Non-GAAP guidance for our operating expenses, which excludes restructuring charges, have been reduced to $375 million to $385 million. [ph] We brought down the high end of this range from $400 million, reflecting our ongoing efforts to manage expenses. 
The non-GAAP operating income guidance has been narrowed to a range of $340 million to $370 million, reflecting the updated net sales and gross margin expectations. 
The non-GAAP effective tax rate has been revised to a range of 8% to 10%, resulting from more favorable jurisdictional mix of income. And keep in mind that this excludes the impact of all restructuring actions and also excludes the impact of the $35 million tax benefit mentioned earlier. 
On a GAAP basis, we expect earnings per share in the range of $3.75 to $3.90. And on a non-GAAP basis, $4.30 to $4.50. As [indiscernible] earlier, we're maintaining the high end of our non-GAAP EPS guidance of $4.50 while tightening the low end to $4.30. The increase in the low end reflects the lower operating expenses and lower expected tax rate. The benefit of project cost reduction in Q3 also helps to offset the impact of the lower revenue from project pushouts. Included in the EPS range is expected Q4 sale of a portion of our remaining interest in Stateline and First Solar share of 8point3 earnings. The equity and earnings amount is approximately $110 million, net of tax. 
Also keep in mind that as mentioned last quarter, the net sales range and gross margin guidance include only a portion of the revenue and none of the deferred profit from the Kingbird sale. Similarly, the EPS guidance provide does not include the $0.16 [indiscernible] Kingbird earnings. Due to the tax equity structure on this project, all earnings have been deferred for the next several years. 
Our operating cash flow guidance provides a range of negative 100 breakeven from prior range of $500 million to $650 million, and the decrease was due to revised sales time in the Moapa and California Flats. 
We're lowering our capital expenditure guidance to revised range of $225 million to $275 million from the prior range of $275 million to $325 million. The timing of certain expenditures have now moved into 2017. 
Net cash guidance has been reduced to $1.4 billion to $1.5 billion as a result of the revised timing of project sales, partially offset by reduction in CapEx. And finally, we're also slightly reducing our shipment guidance for the year based on timing of certain shipments pushing into early 2017. 
Turning to Slide 15. I'll summarize our progress during the third quarter. Our financial results were solid. Revenue of $688 million, GAAP EPS of $1.49 to non-GAAP EPS of $1.22. We maintained the high end of our 2016 GAAP and non-GAAP EPS ranges at $3.90 and $4.50, respectively. Our module efficiency continues to improve steadily and our baseline efficiency exit Q3 running at 16.9%. Our bookings were, of course, lower than expected at approximately 250 megawatts. However, we continue to see growth in a number of potential booking opportunities, including the C&I customers. 
With that, we'll conclude the prepared remarks and open the call for questions. Operator?

headline: First Solar, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 02, 2016

headline: First Solar, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: It seems like you're intending to say is that your -- as you go through this decision-making process or this decision-making process that you may just skip over the [indiscernible] Jan timing straight to Jan 6. With this call a couple of weeks away, what
componenttext: It seems like you're intending to say is that your -- as you go through this decision-making process or this decision-making process that you may just skip over the [indiscernible] Jan timing straight to Jan 6. With this call a couple of weeks away, what can you tell us about the final decision that you're trying to make at this point as we try to get a sense of where we're going to come out in a couple of weeks on this guidance?

headline: First Solar, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: So Colin, what we've done here, we've engaged probably, I guess, maybe 4 to 6 weeks ago, thinking is we put to tiger teams together, if you want to use the term, to do somewhat of a bake-off, right? To look at both Series 5 and Series 6 and what is the ar
componenttext: So Colin, what we've done here, we've engaged probably, I guess, maybe 4 to 6 weeks ago, thinking is we put to tiger teams together, if you want to use the term, to do somewhat of a bake-off, right? To look at both Series 5 and Series 6 and what is the art of the possible and what can we do to further reduce the cost on Series 5 as well as trying to find a path to what can we do to try to accelerate the timing of Series 6. Our long-term plan has always been to have the 2 products coexist, but we're -- given the current market environment, we're evaluating that and trying to make a decision if we can get the cost profile to Series 5 down to a level which we think it needs to be to give us acceptable margins on the sale of that product, then we'll move forward with that transition. If we're not able to do that, we may look to move straight into a Series 6 platform [indiscernible] to pull the product forward as quickly as possible. We've been having ongoing discussions with our internal teams. We've had ongoing discussions with subcommittees within our board, and we'll have our final review with the board next week. And we'll make a decision from there. And whatever that decision is, we'll make sure that we communicate that to everyone on the earnings call on the 16th.

headline: First Solar, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: And we'll take our next question from Tyler Frank with Robert W. Baird.
componenttext: And we'll take our next question from Tyler Frank with Robert W. Baird.

headline: First Solar, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: A couple of large utilities, including Southern Company, and NextEra, recently announced that they were going to limit their spending on solar projects. There were going to focus more on other renewables, including wind, going forward. Can you just tell u
componenttext: A couple of large utilities, including Southern Company, and NextEra, recently announced that they were going to limit their spending on solar projects. There were going to focus more on other renewables, including wind, going forward. Can you just tell us how much that might impact things and sort of what you're seeing for the utility-scale landscape right now, including the competitive environment?

headline: First Solar, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. So I think NextEra and Southern announced based on how they view the economics and risk report of solar projects that are going to perhaps reduce spending in solar and look toward wind. I think neither said that they're going to be exiting the solar
componenttext: Yes. So I think NextEra and Southern announced based on how they view the economics and risk report of solar projects that are going to perhaps reduce spending in solar and look toward wind. I think neither said that they're going to be exiting the solar market. And we clearly have good relationships with both of those 2 counterparties. They'll still be looking for high-quality assets. I think we're both well positioned to meet the opportunities. What we have seen clearly in the latter half of '16 and going to '17 is there is a somewhat of a scarcity of tax capacity for large utility-scale asset. That being said, given the [indiscernible] extension timing, there's also a [indiscernible] asset going into 2017. So think the 2 are somewhat balanced out well there maybe a little more challenging tax capacity issues at some point. The other thing I would say is that we feel that we bring certainly high-quality projects to the market. And given the quality of the project, development, the relationships we have with counterparties in the market, we don't see a significant concern today for us in finding buyers and tax capacity for assets. It may be that, further down the chain, there's some people are struggling, who are [indiscernible] not seeing that reflected in our markets today.

headline: First Solar, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 02, 2016

headline: First Solar, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: I wanted to just better understand what kind of component margins would be acceptable, assuming you're able to lower your costs for Series 5 or maybe even Series 6, when you guys start ramping? I don't assume that you're going to get back to the 25%, 26%
componenttext: I wanted to just better understand what kind of component margins would be acceptable, assuming you're able to lower your costs for Series 5 or maybe even Series 6, when you guys start ramping? I don't assume that you're going to get back to the 25%, 26% levels that you've seen in the past. And then can you maybe talk about Q4 -- is your revenue outlook for Q4 mostly all component shipments? Are you also assuming some systems?

headline: First Solar, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. In terms of the margin profile for our component module sale, in our view, our entitlement still should be in that 20% range. There's no reason to believe that we shouldn't be able to achieve those types of margin. And what we need to make sure is th
componenttext: Yes. In terms of the margin profile for our component module sale, in our view, our entitlement still should be in that 20% range. There's no reason to believe that we shouldn't be able to achieve those types of margin. And what we need to make sure is that we can deliver that with a Series 5 product, and that's what we're working on trying to get the cost down to a point where we think we'll clear the market and still be able to deliver margins that are in that range. I mean, our expectation is that a Series 6 product will deliver even better margin. So I wouldn't want to change our view long-term expectations around gross margin for our module-only sales. With our Series 4 product today, given the smaller form factor, it will make even today's pricing environment more challenging to achieve those types of margins, and we would obviously most likely see margins much lower than the 20%. That's what precipitates the need to transition to either Series 5 or 6 to normalize the form factor delta that we have today in the marketplace and generally drives the slightly lower value for the product. As it relates to Q4 and our mix of revenue, there is still some systems revenue in the fourth quarter, but you will see a significantly high portion of it be module-only sales.

headline: First Solar, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: In the recent past, you've talked about a 3-gigawatt year for 2017 and 2 gigawatts [ph] for external modules and 1 gigawatt for systems. I know you have your call coming up and so forth. But you have talked about this in the past. With California flats an
componenttext: In the recent past, you've talked about a 3-gigawatt year for 2017 and 2 gigawatts [ph] for external modules and 1 gigawatt for systems. I know you have your call coming up and so forth. But you have talked about this in the past. With California flats and Moapa slated for '17 now, that brings in more than 500 megawatts of systems to '17. So how should we be thinking about volumes now for '17? Is it more of a 3.5-gigawatt target?

headline: First Solar, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. So I think we'll discuss capacity on the call in a couple of weeks. As it relates to both Moapa and Cal Flats, we'll be completing the sale of those assets in 2017 with a significant portion of the modules shipped in 2016. When you look to the 2017 s
componenttext: Yes. So I think we'll discuss capacity on the call in a couple of weeks. As it relates to both Moapa and Cal Flats, we'll be completing the sale of those assets in 2017 with a significant portion of the modules shipped in 2016. When you look to the 2017 shipment numbers that we've discussed previously, the approximately 3 gigawatts split systems to 0 [ph] module, the total capacity we discuss again in a couple of weeks. If you look at the systems business today, we booked approximately 550 megawatts of system shipments in 2017 today. We have about one another 100 megawatts of relatively late-stage opportunities. It takes us to between 600 to 700 megawatts. Beyond that, we have seen some opportunities fall out of the pipeline. So as Mark mentioned in his comments earlier, in Egypt, we've seen some opportunities go by the wayside there based on development issues. And likewise, we passed on opportunities in India and Africa based on pricing where we will chase the pricing if [indiscernible] if it were going to be uneconomic for us. So if you look at 2017 today, I think we're confident in a 600 to 700-megawatt number in terms of the shipments, which is less than we hoped for, but we also continue to have a robust pipeline and continue to look for other opportunities.

componenttextpreview: I know the -- just over 500 megawatts of Moapa and California Flats shifting into 2017, and it looks like that seems to be the main reason for, what, 700 basis point increase in margin -- gross margin in 2016. That's for the full year? I mean, I haven't d
componenttext: I know the -- just over 500 megawatts of Moapa and California Flats shifting into 2017, and it looks like that seems to be the main reason for, what, 700 basis point increase in margin -- gross margin in 2016. That's for the full year? I mean, I haven't done the math yet, but the implied gross margin on those projects are very low, arguably in the single digits? Am I correct? And what does this mean for 2017 gross margins?

headline: First Solar, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. So what I'm saying is there are 2 things impacting that margin. One is we've had good execution on projects this year. So that's the project savings that push the numbers higher than expected. The other piece, the 2 assets we're referencing both Moap
componenttext: Yes. So what I'm saying is there are 2 things impacting that margin. One is we've had good execution on projects this year. So that's the project savings that push the numbers higher than expected. The other piece, the 2 assets we're referencing both Moapa and Cal Flats, legacy assets that had some unique challenges to them that made them lower gross margins than you would otherwise see on the [indiscernible] basis. The Moapa is an asset that we acquired in late-stage development and therefore paid a development premium to acquire. On Cal Flats, we have one this redevelopment issue, which is resolved, would increase that margin significantly, but that's not currently in the guidance number. But those 2 assets have some unique differences from what I would say the typical development projects. If you look out into 2017, we don't have, I think, significant similar challenges on the assets that we have in 2017. And then going out beyond that, majority of our California pipeline out to 2018 and 2019 is at higher margin level. We think that all expected [indiscernible]

componenttextpreview: Can you go into a little bit more detail on Stateline recognition here, just in terms of the project sale process with Kathy? You said you assumed a certain percentage. Can you elaborate a little bit, a, what the percentage is? And B, what the sort of nua
componenttext: Can you go into a little bit more detail on Stateline recognition here, just in terms of the project sale process with Kathy? You said you assumed a certain percentage. Can you elaborate a little bit, a, what the percentage is? And B, what the sort of nuances around where that will come out? And what that upside could be? If you at least get some parameters around what that aspect could be.

headline: First Solar, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. Julian, as you know, 8point3 has gone out and recently got an equity raise plus they also expanded their credit agreement. They had [indiscernible] agreement expanded that. I think the capacity was around $250 million. They have also recently acquire
componenttext: Yes. Julian, as you know, 8point3 has gone out and recently got an equity raise plus they also expanded their credit agreement. They had [indiscernible] agreement expanded that. I think the capacity was around $250 million. They have also recently acquired Henrietta. And so they're using the capacity for that. So what we're trying to do with 8point3 is there is limited capacity in terms of their ability to acquire the entire interest. Clearly, there is an interest from 8point3 to do that. We are trying to work through structuring around that and see if we can accomplish that. And to the extent that we can, then we'll be able to sell 100% of our remaining interest, which was 34% of Stateline. We have left out of the guidance approximately 25% of the value, which is dependent upon our ability to go above and beyond or find ways to sell 100%, even though there's not, today, presently, decisions capacity to acquire 100% interest in Stateline, given the available cash and debt capacity that 8point3 has at this point in time. So we're just looking through options. So we -- in our guidance, we've excluded a portion of the sale, and that's about 25% of the remaining interest.

componenttext: We'll take our next question from Brian Lee with Goldman Sachs.

headline: First Solar, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: Just had a couple. First, on California Flats, what sort of timing should we expect in 2017? And then given the EPS range basically unchanged here with a few of the benefits from other lines, back into about $0.80 of EPS at the midpoint, that Cal Flats an
componenttext: Just had a couple. First, on California Flats, what sort of timing should we expect in 2017? And then given the EPS range basically unchanged here with a few of the benefits from other lines, back into about $0.80 of EPS at the midpoint, that Cal Flats and Moapa represented, is that reasonable? And would it change now that you're monetizing those assets later? And then just quickly, on the updated guidance for 2016, the non-GAAP tax rate. Could you reconcile what exactly is driving the sort of $0.40 of EPS relative to your prior guidance?

headline: First Solar, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: I guess, Brian, on the tax rate, I think what you're seeing is the delta between the GAAP and the non-GAAP. First off, we highlighted that we had a favorable ruling on an item in an international jurisdiction, which was worth about $35 million or about $0
componenttext: I guess, Brian, on the tax rate, I think what you're seeing is the delta between the GAAP and the non-GAAP. First off, we highlighted that we had a favorable ruling on an item in an international jurisdiction, which was worth about $35 million or about $0.35. We embedded in our GAAP numbers, but that's not reflected in our non-GAAP numbers, okay? So that's kind of the primary delta between the 2. The other side of it is relative to our prior outlook on the tax rate. We have a favorable mix of income. So what's happened now with the drop in revenue, that drives a different result in terms of where is the income by jurisdictional mix with each jurisdictional mix has a different tax rate associated with it. And as you know, we have a tax holiday in Malaysia. So more of the income is represented in Malaysia as a percent of total will drive down the overall tax rate. So that's kind of the event driving the change in the tax rate both on a GAAP and a non-GAAP basis from the prior guidance that we've provided in Q2 earnings call. Brian, I'm not really sure how you're getting the $0.80 or so for Moapa and CA Flat. I think Paul had it right when he referenced it. When he look at the revenue delta, which is close to $1 billion, and if you look at the gross margin rate increasing, but when you look at the total gross margin dollars not changing significantly, you would look to it and say, "Well, that would imply that the gross margin on growth of those assets is lower than normally expected for system business." I think Alex walked through that as well. So we can take it off-line, if you like. You can spend more time with you, but you should not get anywhere close to -- I think you referenced around $0.80 of the value for the pushout of those 2 [ph] projects. It will be significantly lower than that.

headline: First Solar, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: I was wondering if you could give us some sense with your expanding O&M portfolio. What are the economics of those contracts? What did they look like? And how should we think about the contribution of the type of business going forward?
componenttext: I was wondering if you could give us some sense with your expanding O&M portfolio. What are the economics of those contracts? What did they look like? And how should we think about the contribution of the type of business going forward?

headline: First Solar, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: So the O&M business, again, it's a good business. It's a recurring annuity stream relatively high fixed cost. Therefore, variable line. It had a very high contribution rate. And the profile on the business, if you look at it over time, the margins can ran
componenttext: So the O&M business, again, it's a good business. It's a recurring annuity stream relatively high fixed cost. Therefore, variable line. It had a very high contribution rate. And the profile on the business, if you look at it over time, the margins can range -- the margin on average are above the average for the business. They also will be much higher, let's say, in the first 5 or 6 years of the contract. If you look at the performance of the plan as well as the warranties that you have with inverter manufacturers and others, you'll generally realize much higher margins within the first 5 to 7 years. And then as you approach just kind of 10 to 15 years, you may see margins start to drop off a little bit, especially if you had to do overall -- with [indiscernible] in those of things, but it's a good margin business. It's one that is really based off of scale, and we aren't looking to -- we have a strong presence here in the U.S. We're looking to grow it and capture the benefit of the infrastructure. Our network operating Center and investments we made over the years to monitor plants and try to find other ways to optimize the performance of the plants that there's -- it's a good base business that has great opportunity to continue to grow. The revenue dollars won't be sizable in general relative to the total, but it can contribute meaningful gross margin and EPS.

headline: First Solar, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: We'll take our next question from Chris Sankar our with Bank of America.
componenttext: We'll take our next question from Chris Sankar our with Bank of America.

headline: First Solar, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: Mark, I'd like a longer-term question. 3 months ago, you guys spoke about Series 5 being probably 1 gigawatt in 2017 and then as the module price continued to decline 15%, it's forcibly deleting the strategy. Kind of curious, if module price continues to
componenttext: Mark, I'd like a longer-term question. 3 months ago, you guys spoke about Series 5 being probably 1 gigawatt in 2017 and then as the module price continued to decline 15%, it's forcibly deleting the strategy. Kind of curious, if module price continues to decline another 25% to 30% over the next 12 months or 18 months, would Series 6 be highly profitable? And what are the levels you have for lowering your overall cost at this point?

headline: First Solar, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: So a couple of things. Around Series 5, in particular, is that -- what we're focused on Series 5. I want to make sure it's clear, is that if we can further cost reduce and then we're looking at ways to do that. The product will be highly competitive. So I
componenttext: So a couple of things. Around Series 5, in particular, is that -- what we're focused on Series 5. I want to make sure it's clear, is that if we can further cost reduce and then we're looking at ways to do that. The product will be highly competitive. So I don't wanted to be looked upon that it's a direct correlation that the ASPs to decline. And therefore, the product is not -- no longer competitive. It is an advantage product relative to Series 4 because it solves our difference in form factor, which drives -- generally drives the higher balance of plant cost. So it's a very valuable product from that standpoint. The challenge that was getting -- there is some incremental cost that we're adding to the model and in terms of rails and other things along those lines. So it can drive to a higher cost point than Series 4, but the general benefit of the larger form factor is offsetting the impact of that higher cost. What we're trying to find a way is that can we further cost reduce some of the incremental components for Series 5 or just about the material or other ways of driving out cost on Series 5 that we can get it to a position that we feel more comfortable in competing in marketplace and capturing the market risk profile that we would like. The other thing I think it's important to understand is that, if -- when we first embarked on our vision for Series 6, it was a little over a year ago. And we have had tremendous learning around Series 6 that dealt with some of the potential constraints or challenges and/or risk that we had with Series 6 when we first sat down and created the business case. If we had known everything that we know as of now for Series 6, we may have made a decision to go straight to Series 6, okay? So some of it is -- ASPs in this -- in the market decline, that's putting some pressure on Series 5. We've got a further cost reduce it. If we can do that, then we'll continue with the transition. However, we also have an opportunity to meaningfully pull forward Series 6 and getting that product into market faster. Then we just have to compare the trade-offs between the 2 and make a decision on which path we want to go. Series 6 at any price point that we're seeing in the market right now will exceed any of our expectations around margins and what we believe that business -- that entitlement should be. So we're very confident with the Series 6 around its efficiency as well as the cost entitlement, and generate all the energy yield benefits around temperature coefficient, spectral response, diffuse shading, everything you could possibly -- obviously, we've talked about around [indiscernible] technology still resides in Series 6. So we can just have much higher efficiency, much greater energy density at a much lower cost point.

headline: First Solar, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: Back in April, at the Analyst Day, you talked about the price advantage that you can get in hot climate areas such as India. With the module pricing meltdown since then industrywide, have you been able to retain then advantage in the hot climates or has t
componenttext: Back in April, at the Analyst Day, you talked about the price advantage that you can get in hot climate areas such as India. With the module pricing meltdown since then industrywide, have you been able to retain then advantage in the hot climates or has that kind of dissipated away?

headline: First Solar, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: No. Look, the [indiscernible] value from the benefits are there and were able to capture that. In India is a great market for a product and the one we can capture meaningful, incremental value for the energy that we provide. So there's nothing's changed.
componenttext: No. Look, the [indiscernible] value from the benefits are there and were able to capture that. In India is a great market for a product and the one we can capture meaningful, incremental value for the energy that we provide. So there's nothing's changed. The environment doesn't change that. What has some impact, not necessarily around percent energy advantage, but the value of the energy can be impacted with PPA prices. So I mean it's intuitive, the lowered PPA price, therefore the lower the value of the energy. So there is some kind of impact on that as BPA prices, in some markets, have gotten very aggressive. But the inherent energy value is still there. The percent deltas are still there. The only real dynamic that can change the equation around what is translated ASP is "What is the underlying PPA generally lower PPA means less value in ASP."
